The Fund Manager may initiate the replacement of a Trustee if it believes the Trustee is unable to discharge its functions, subject to the Regulator's prior written approval [#P:7f8bd5cb-a931-4221-a9cd-a5ac3f7ab58a].
question: When can the Regulator allow a new Trustee to replace the old one, and what does it mean for the Trustee to be independent from the Fund Manager?

gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must demonstrate compliance with the Corporate Governance framework requirements under Section 73(2) of the FSMR by illustrating in its annual report how its actual practices align with the intended outcomes of prudent and sound management [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]. The Regulator has the authority to prescribe specific Corporate Governance principles and standards, which may include requirements for the board of Directors, individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other relevant persons [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d]. The Reporting Entity should ensure that these prescribed standards are reflected in its governance practices to meet the Regulator's expectations.
pred_answer: A Reporting Entity must demonstrate compliance with the Corporate Governance framework requirements under Section 73(2) of the FSMR by ensuring its framework is adequate to promote prudent and sound long-term management, and by illustrating how its actual practices achieve the intended outcomes of Section 73 and the Corporate Governance Principles. [#P:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] The Corporate Governance Principles, prescribed pursuant to Section 73 of the FSMR, are mandatory high-level requirements, with APP 4 setting out best practice standards that Reporting Entities may adopt to achieve compliance. [#P:1ea12f12-0a82-44e8-96b5-59d5a233d835, #P:9178e112-8d6d-4fcd-931f-7c3f5ecdc2de] As part of its annual financial report, a Listed Entity must state whether it has adopted the best practice standards in APP 4. [#P:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If these standards are not fully or only partially adopted, the Reporting Entity must explain the reasons for this and detail any alternative measures taken to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles. [#P:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e, #P:129d03d7-18a7-46fc-853b-0f2c7c3c21b5] Furthermore, the Board of Directors must provide a statement in the annual report assessing the effectiveness of the Corporate Governance framework in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, including supporting information, assumptions, and qualifications. [#P:11d02cca, #P:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Failure to disclose accurate information regarding adoption of best practices may lead to civil liability. [#P:ff5bac8d-3dc7-
question: How must a Reporting Entity demonstrate compliance with the Corporate Governance framework requirements under Section 73(2) of the FSMR, considering the Regulator's authority to prescribe principles and standards?

gold_answer: Compliance with other legislative requirements would be deemed sufficient for the Board of a Listed Entity and its individual Directors if those requirements are similar or more stringent than the requirements outlined in this section. This is applicable when the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 is subject to such legislation [#SRC:a5757384-c175-4202-9235-9870610be21f]. The section specifically applies to the Board of a Listed Entity and each individual Director who is a member of such a Board [#TGT:2669439e-beee-42e0-90fd-9b8bbdac7183].
pred_answer: Compliance with other legislative requirements is deemed sufficient for the Board of a Listed Entity and its individual Directors when those other requirements are similar to or more stringent than the requirements outlined in Section 9.3.1 of the applicable legislation [#P:a5757384-c175-4202-9235-9870610be21f]. This section specifically applies to the Board of a Listed Entity and each individual Director who is a member of such a Board [#P:2669439e-beee-42e0-90fd-9b8bbdac7183]. The core principle is that if a Person is mandated by any applicable legislation to adhere to requirements that are either identical or more rigorous than those stipulated in this section, then fulfilling those external obligations will satisfy the corresponding internal requirements [#P:a5757384-c175-4202-9235-9870610be21f]. For instance, if company law or other applicable legislation in a Listed Entity's jurisdiction of incorporation mandates more stringent procedures, such as a special resolution for a reduction of share capital (requiring at least 75% of shareholder votes), compliance with these stricter rules would be sufficient for meeting the requirements of Rule 9.3.8, which pertains to shareholder approval by a simple majority [#P:5bb66021-ab87-4bd3-af05-70a7bc1f5724]. This provision ensures that entities are not penalized for adhering to higher standards imposed by their local legal frameworks.
question: Under what circumstances would compliance with other legislative requirements be deemed sufficient for the Board of a Listed Entity and its individual Directors, as per the application of this section?

gold_answer: Yes, an Authorised Person must apply the COBS Rules, including Rule 3.4 on Suitability and Rule 6.5 on Best Execution, to all transactions involving Virtual Assets. This requirement holds irrespective of any restrictions or exceptions to these Rules elsewhere in COBS [#TGT:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e]. The application of these Rules is specifically mandated for Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities related to Virtual Assets [#SRC:3483a783-5aa5-4a3d-8e88-9c26ba4bed8a].
pred_answer: Yes, an Authorised Person must apply COBS Rule 3.4 (Suitability) and COBS Rule 6.5 (Best Execution) to all transactions undertaken when conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, irrespective of any restrictions or exceptions to these Rules elsewhere in COBS [#P:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e]. This requirement is explicitly stated within the Virtual Asset Framework for Authorised Persons [#P:3483a783-5aa5-4a3d-8e88-9c26ba4bed8a]. The specific COBS Rules that apply universally to all transactions involving Virtual Assets conducted by an Authorised Person engaged in a Regulated Activity are COBS Rule 3.4 (Suitability), COBS Rule 6.5 (Best Execution), COBS Rule 6.7 (Aggregation and Allocation), COBS Rule 6.10 (Confirmation Notes), COBS Rule 6.11 (Periodic Statements), and COBS Chapter 12 (Key Information and Client Agreement) [#P:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e, #P:3483a783-5aa5-4a3d-8e88-9c26ba4bed8a]. These rules are to be read as applying to all such transactions, overriding any other limitations or exceptions found elsewhere in COBS [#P:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e].
question: Must an Authorised Person apply the COBS Rules, specifically Rule 3.4 on Suitability and Rule 6.5 on Best Execution, to all transactions involving Virtual Assets, even if there are restrictions or exceptions elsewhere in COBS?

gold_answer: An issue of Securities can be considered approved later if it didn't exceed the initial limit, the holders of the company's Ordinary Securities approve it afterward, and the Securities are issued within three months of that approval [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6]. This later approval affects how many new Equity Securities a company can issue without needing more approval because the calculation includes Securities issued in the past 12 months that were approved or considered approved under Rule 9.7.1 [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
pred_answer: An issue of securities, initially made without approval under Rule 9.7.1, can be treated as having been approved if specific conditions are met, allowing it to be considered under Rule 9.7.5. [#P:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] This subsequent approval impacts the calculation of new Equity Securities a company can issue without further approval by potentially reducing the "Relevant Issues" count. [#P:11,9.7.1,PID=a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] For an issue or agreement to be treated as approved under Rule 9.7.5, it must not have exceeded the limit stipulated in Rule 9.7.1, the holders of the Listed Entity's Ordinary Securities must subsequently approve it, and the securities must be issued within three months of the date of this approval. [#P:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] If this three-month period lapses without the securities being issued, the approval will lapse, and the securities will then be counted within "Relevant Issues" for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1. [#P:6afde8f2-e0c2-4a55-afca-5f5b7d3cea35,76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] When calculating the number of Equity Securities that may be issued under Rule 9.7.1, including those contributing to "Relevant Issues," each fully paid Ordinary Security is counted as one, each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up, and each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted, unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#P:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]
question: When can an issue of Securities be considered approved later, and how does this affect the number of new Equity Securities a company can issue without needing more approval?

gold_answer: An Investigator may enter business premises without prior notice if they determine that providing such notice could prejudice the investigation [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. During this entry, the Investigator can require the Person Under Investigation or any other person to permit entry during normal business hours for inspecting and copying documents [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
pred_answer: An Investigator may enter business premises without prior notice if they consider it appropriate, particularly when providing advance notice might prejudice the investigation [#P:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980]. This power, exercised under section 206(1)(e) of FSMR, allows the Investigator to enter during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying documents relevant to the investigation [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046, #P:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. During such an entry, the Investigator can require any appropriate person to make available any relevant information stored at the premises for inspection or copying, or to convert such information into a form capable of being copied [#P:b96ffe87-e2fd-46b4-bca9-4f03ea, #P:f532338d-345e-4a5e-89c2-8623a18e0fa0]. Additionally, the Investigator may use the facilities of the occupier of the premises, free of charge, to make copies [#P:b96ffe87-e2fd-46b4-bca9-4f03ea, #P:f532338d-345e-4a5e-89c2-8623a18e0fa0]. Any requirement imposed by the Investigator, including permission to enter premises, must be relevant to the purposes of the investigation [#P:7a5481df-9205-4b13-85d9-3c5b66a3cf74]. While written notice of the exercise of the power to enter is generally given, there is no requirement for advance notice in certain circumstances [#P:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980].
question: Under what conditions may an Investigator enter business premises without prior notice, and what actions can they require from the Person Under Investigation or others during such an entry?

gold_answer: A Spot Commodity can be called an Accepted Spot Commodity if it follows responsible sourcing standards and international certifications [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]. The Regulator checks the market's liquidity, demand, supply, and transparency [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]. It must be a good sold for cash and delivered promptly, not a future or financial instrument, and can include an Environmental Instrument as a carbon offset [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068].
pred_answer:
A Spot Commodity can be designated an Accepted Spot Commodity when an Authorised Person demonstrates to the FSRA that it meets specific requirements, allowing for its use in Regulated Activities. [#P:be5097e2-d888-4c74-9f12-d9fd79a5d57e] The FSRA considers several factors to determine if a Spot Commodity qualifies as "Accepted," focusing on responsible sourcing, market fundamentals, and delivery soundness. [#P:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338, #P:be5097e2-d888-4c74-9f12-d9fd79a5d57e]

The Regulator's checks on market fundamentals include:
*   Assessing the market practice and characteristics of the relevant Spot Commodity. [#P:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338, #P:be5097e2-d888-4c74-9f12-d9fd79a5d57e]
*   Evaluating its liquidity, and the depth and breadth of demand and supply. [#P:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338, #P:be5097e2-d888-4c74-9f12-d9fd79a5d57e]
*   Considering the number of active participants in the market. [#P:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338, #P:be5097e2-d888-4c74-9f12-d9fd79a5d57e]
*   Examining market transparency and its fair and orderly operation. [#P:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b73
question: When can a Spot Commodity be called an Accepted Spot Commodity, and what does the Regulator check about the market?

gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must include specific information when disclosing new estimates of Prospective Resources that are material and have not been previously disclosed. The disclosure must contain the types of permits or licenses held for the disclosed estimates [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. Additionally, it should describe the method of estimation, any further Exploration activities planned, and the expected timing of these activities [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. The entity must also assess the likelihood of discovery and development and explain relevant risk factors [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. This disclosure must also consider any changes or additions to previously disclosed information relating to Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4) [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].
pred_answer: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses new material estimates of Prospective Resources that have not been previously disclosed, the disclosure must contain specific information regarding the permits or licenses held, a description of exploration activities and their timing, the entity's assessment of discovery and development likelihood, and an explanation of relevant risk factors [#P:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. This initial disclosure requirement is triggered when there has been a material change in estimates compared to when they were last disclosed, or if they are being disclosed for the first time [#P:06904fa1-376e-475a-8214-a5a1f6812348]. Furthermore, any subsequent disclosure that refers to these estimates must reference the earlier disclosure and confirm that no new material information or data affects the prior disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters continue to apply and have not materially changed [#P:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]. This is in addition to the general requirement that any new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed must be immediately disclosed [#P:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12]. The disclosure must also include any changes or additions to previously disclosed information relating to Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves [#P:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].
question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses new estimates of Prospective Resources that are material and have not been previously disclosed, what specific information must be included in the disclosure, and how does this relate to any changes or additions to previously disclosed information?

gold_answer: The Greenshoe Option may be exercised only when Relevant Securities have been over allotted during Ancillary Stabilisation [#SRC:a4e4d44f-4fae-4648-880f-1450a2b98fc4]. The exercise period for the Greenshoe Option must coincide with the Stabilisation Window, which begins on the date of admission to trading of Relevant Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange and ends no later than thirty days thereafter [#TGT:21eb4260-16a2-4970-990b-21d85832e1c0].
pred_answer: A Greenshoe Option may be exercised during Ancillary Stabilisation only where Relevant Securities have been over-allotted, and its exercise is subject to specific conditions related to the original offer size and the exercise period, which must align with the Stabilisation Window. [#P:a4e4d44f-4fae-4648-880f-1450a2b98fc4] The exercise of the Greenshoe Option must be promptly disclosed to the public with all appropriate details, including the date of exercise and the number and nature of Relevant Securities involved. [#P:a4e4d44f-4fae-4648-880f-1450a2b98fc4] The Stabilisation Window, during which Price Stabilisation activities, including the exercise of the Greenshoe Option, may occur, begins on the date of admission to trading of Relevant Securities and concludes no later than thirty days thereafter. [#P:21eb4260-16a2-4970-990b-21d85832e1c0] Furthermore, the Greenshoe Option cannot amount to more than 15% of the original Offer, and any position resulting from the exercise of an Overallotment Facility not covered by the Greenshoe Option may not exceed 5% of the original Offer. [#P:a4e4d44f-4fae-4648-880f-1450a2b98fc4] The existence and maximum size of any Overallotment Facility or Greenshoe Option, along with its exercise period and any conditions for its use, must be publicly disclosed before the offer period opens. [#P:c345d24e-7ea9-4397-8ea5-a0d5c2e25447]
question: What are the conditions under which a Greenshoe Option may be exercised during Ancillary Stabilisation, and how does the timing of the Stabilisation Window relate to this process?

gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure that any Prospectus including statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets complies with Rule 11.2.1, as well as the requirements of Chapter 4 [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9]. Additionally, the disclosure must adhere to a Mining Reporting Standard and the relevant chapter [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. The Prospectus must also detail the Mining Reporting Entity's policies and practices regarding sustainable operations, including their environmental and social policies, the impact of their business practices on the environment and communities, and the environmental and social risks they face [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9].
pred_answer: A Prospectus that includes statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets must comply with specific regulatory obligations beyond the general requirements of Chapter 4. These disclosures must adhere to Rule 11.2.1, meaning they must be prepared in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and the requirements of MKT Chapter 11 [#P:7, #P:10]. Furthermore, such a Prospectus must also comply with Rule 11.2.1 in its entirety, ensuring all disclosures within it meet the specified standards [#P:7]. In addition to these reporting standards, the Prospectus must also include details regarding the Mining Reporting Entity's policies and practices for sustainable operations. This includes outlining the entity's policy on environmental and social issues, detailing the impact of its business practices on the environment and communities, and identifying the environmental and social risks it faces [#P:1]. Importantly, any disclosure containing these elements must not include Historical Estimates [#P:8].
question: What are the obligations of a Mining Reporting Entity when a Prospectus includes statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets, and how do these relate to sustainable operating practices?

gold_answer: A Specified Benchmark Information Provider that is also a Price Reporting Agency must adhere to the requirements of MIR Rule 3.11.2, along with the rules specified in section 21.4 [#SRC:3af22e09-3d07-428f-8ca0-13b059f75329]. This includes having fair and non-discriminatory procedures for setting prices of Financial Instruments, which should be publicly available [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Additionally, the agency must ensure transparency in its pricing methodology and calculations, allowing users to understand how benchmarks or indices are derived and any limitations they may have [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
pred_answer: If a Specified Benchmark Information Provider is also a Price Reporting Agency, it must comply with MIR Rule 3.11.2 in addition to other specified requirements. [#P:3af22e09-3d07-428f-8ca0-13b059f75329] To ensure fair pricing and transparency, such an agency must adhere to several key obligations. These include establishing public, fair, and non-discriminatory procedures for determining the prices of Financial Instruments. [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] Furthermore, the agency must demonstrate sufficient transparency regarding its methodology, calculation processes, and the inputs used, enabling users to comprehend how benchmarks or indices are derived and their potential limitations. [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] When making assessments, priority should be given to concluded transactions, and measures must be implemented to minimize selective reporting. [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] The agency must also maintain good standing as an independent and objective provider, possess a sound corporate governance framework, and implement adequate arrangements to manage conflicts of interest that could materially impact price determination. [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] Finally, robust complaint resolution mechanisms are required to address any issues concerning its assessment process and methodology. [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]
question: If a Specified Benchmark Information Provider is also a Price Reporting Agency, what rules must they follow to ensure fair pricing and transparency?

gold_answer: The Regulator is prohibited from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) if it determines that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may not comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if it is necessary to refrain from doing so to meet its objectives [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a]. This prohibition is relevant to the timing of providing notice of intent to use passporting procedures, as the Regulator must provide such notice within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2, subject to Rule 3.2.5 [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e].
pred_answer: The Regulator is prohibited from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply, or may in the future not comply, with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if it deems it necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so to further its objectives [#P:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a]. This prohibition directly impacts the timing of providing notice of intent to use passporting procedures, as the Regulator must first assess compliance and its objectives before proceeding with the notification to the Host Regulator(s). If these conditions for prohibition are met, the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) cannot be transmitted, thereby halting the passporting process at this stage. Otherwise, the Regulator shall provide notice of the intent to use passporting procedures within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2 [#P:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e].
question: Under what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and how does this relate to the timing of providing notice of intent to use passporting procedures?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay an application fee when seeking approval to set up a branch outside ADGM, which is 50% of the highest fee listed in Chapter 3 for the activities they plan to do [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. They also have to pay a supplementary fee if the branch will be in a place where there is no proper agreement between the Regulator and the local financial regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person with its registered head office in ADGM must pay an application fee when seeking approval from the Regulator to establish a branch outside ADGM. [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] This fee is equivalent to 50% of the highest application fee stipulated in Chapter 3 of the Rules for the Regulated Activities intended to be conducted from the proposed branch. [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] Furthermore, if an Authorised Person already operates a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from it, an annual supervision fee is payable to the Regulator. [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] This annual fee is also set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to those Regulated Activities undertaken from the branch. [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] The initial supervision fee for such a branch is prorated and must be paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a). [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] Additionally, the Regulator reserves the right to impose a supplementary fee if it anticipates incurring substantial additional costs or expending significant effort in processing an application, authorisation, or filing, or in conducting ongoing supervision. [#P:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] An Authorised Person with one or more branches outside ADGM is also required to implement and maintain Credit Risk policies tailored to each local market and its regulatory conditions. [#P:46c299a3-a9ee-4302-864b-f24ddbe4151e]
question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay extra fees to set up a branch outside ADGM?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person should use the lower Collateral value from the stress test when figuring out the Exposure value [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3]. They can also lower Exposures by using specific provisions for credit loss risks, netting claims and liabilities with a Counterparty, holding certain types of Collateral, using eligible guarantees, applying Credit Derivatives, and doing securitisation transactions, as long as they meet the rules in Sections 4.13 and 4.14 [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3].
pred_answer: If the value of Collateral under a stress scenario is lower than the value applied under Rule 4.15.12, the Authorised Person must use the lower value when determining the Exposure value for the purposes of Section 4.15. [#P:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] To lower Exposures, an Authorised Person may consider treating portions of an Exposure as being incurred to a third party if the Exposure is guaranteed by that third party or secured by Collateral issued by that third party, provided certain conditions are met. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] Specifically, if the Collateral meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, the portion of the Exposure secured by Collateral can be treated as an Exposure to the third party providing the Collateral, rather than to the Client, for the purposes of considering limits set out in Rule 4.15.5. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] Similarly, if a guarantee meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, the guaranteed portion of the Exposure can be treated as an Exposure to the third party providing the guarantee, provided there is no Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] Furthermore, if an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and would be assigned a lower risk weight, only the guaranteed portion is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5, and the Authorised Person may also consider exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees. [#P:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c
question: If the Collateral value is lower in a stress test than what Rule 4.15.12 says, what should an Authorised Person do, and what are some ways to lower Exposures?

gold_answer: The restrictions in APP 7 do not apply to an Applicant if, under Rule 9.6.2, the Applicant is not required to apply these restrictions [#SRC:d1edac54-b7c2-4022-81ed-d1385cc550a4]. Additionally, the Regulator may decide that the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, and 9 of APP 7 do not apply to a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15, has an acceptable track record of profitability or revenue, or possesses tangible assets with a substantial proportion of the total asset value [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac].
pred_answer: The restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, and 9 of APP 7 do not apply to a Listed Entity, unless the Regulator decides otherwise, if the entity meets specific criteria outlined in Rule 9.6.2. [#P:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] These criteria include qualifying for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15, possessing a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator, or having tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that constitute a substantial proportion of its total assets, as determined by the Regulator. [#P:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] Furthermore, if under Rule 9.6.2 an Applicant is not required to apply the restrictions in APP 7, then Rules 2.3.16(7)(a) and (b) do not apply. [#P:d1edac54-b7c2-4022-81ed-d1385cc550a4] In general, a Listed Entity which has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities must apply the restrictions in APP 7 or other restrictions as decided by the Regulator. [#P:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] Conversely, if an Applicant has issued, or proposes to issue, Securities that are or are required to be Restricted Securities, it must comply with Rule 9.6 and APP 7, unless an exception under Rule 9.6.2 applies. [#P:b46b5a52-1889-4f0a-ad92-a9dc9a59b53f] The Regulator also retains the discretion to impose conditions or restrictions on the admission of Securities to the Official List. [#P:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]
question: Under what circumstances are the restrictions in APP 7 not applicable to an Applicant, considering both Rule 9.6.2 and the Regulator's discretion regarding Listed Entities?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person must relinquish their Financial Services Permission (FSP) upon obtaining a Recognition Order to operate a Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764]. The Recognition Order must include a stipulation that permits the Recognised Investment Exchange to carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]. If such a stipulation is included, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but only to that function [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person operating a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) who wishes to also operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange (RIE) must relinquish their Financial Services Provider (FSP) upon obtaining a Recognition Order to operate the RIE [#P:137, #P:78, #P:68]. If the FSRA licenses an Authorised Person to conduct both activities, the relevant Recognition Order will stipulate this arrangement, pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1 [#P:137, #P:78, #P:68]. This means that an RIE, in addition to its existing markets for financial instruments, can operate a separate MTF or an MTF using Virtual Assets, provided its Recognition Order includes a specific stipulation permitting this [#P:136, #P:77, #P:137]. If such a stipulation is granted, the RIE must comply with the Virtual Asset Framework for its MTF operations using virtual assets, while its other operations must adhere to the MIR Rules [#P:137]. Furthermore, an RIE operating an MTF or an Over-the-Counter (OTF) must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements [#P:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d].
question: Under what conditions must an Authorised Person relinquish their FSP when transitioning from operating an MTF to a Recognised Investment Exchange, and how does the Recognition Order affect their ability to operate an MTF or OTF?

gold_answer: A FinTech Participant must follow certain rules to control client impact and get authorised under the RegLab. The Regulator will set limits on clients and exposure to manage the test activities' scope and scale, protecting client interests with geographical restrictions [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]. The applicant must show they have enough resources and experience, define test parameters, and propose a reporting schedule [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d]. They also need to detail safeguards and have a plan for clients if the FinTech Proposal changes or ends [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d].
pred_answer: To control client impact and gain authorization under the RegLab framework, a FinTech Participant must demonstrate to the Regulator's satisfaction that it meets specific requirements and adheres to imposed limitations. The Regulator will implement measures such as setting client and exposure limits, and imposing geographical restrictions to manage the scope and scale of test activities and protect client interests [#P:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]. Authorization necessitates satisfying Threshold Conditions, including having adequate resources, being fit and proper, and possessing relevant knowledge and experience [#P:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d]. Furthermore, the applicant must clearly define test parameters, control boundaries, milestones, and intended outcomes, propose an acceptable reporting schedule, detail appropriate safeguards for clients and risks, and outline a fair exit strategy for clients [#P:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d]. The Regulator may also impose specific conditions on the FinTech Participant's activities, such as limitations on the number and type of clients, transaction types and sizes, requirements for client consent, and rules regarding client money, investments, and information handling [#P:2ab073ac-5815-4b31-9686-7b49809deef0]. Adherence to all applicable ADGM Regulations, Rules, conditions, and limitations prescribed by the Regulator is also mandatory [#P:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d].
question: What must a FinTech Participant do to control client impact and get authorised under the RegLab?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 fee to the Regulator when it conducts certain financial activities. The $100,000 fee is due if the Authorised Person is allowed to Accept Deposits or Provide Credit [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. The $10,000 fee is required if the Authorised Person does both activities in Rule 3.3.2 or manages a Profit Sharing Investment Account and provides credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. So, if the Authorised Person provides credit and either accepts deposits or manages a profit-sharing account, both fees apply.
pred_answer: An Authorised Person must pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 annual supervision fee to the Regulator when they are carrying on both Regulated Activities listed under Rule 3.3.2 and also the Regulated Activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit. Specifically, the $100,000 fee is payable by an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either Accepting Deposits or Providing Credit [#P:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. In addition to this, an Authorised Person must pay an additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 if they are carrying on both Regulated Activities mentioned in Rule 3.3.2, or if they are engaged in both Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit [#P:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. This means that if an Authorised Person is undertaking the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Providing Credit (incurring the $100,000 fee) and also Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit (incurring the additional $10,000 fee), they would be liable for both fees. The rules also state that an Authorised Person undertaking multiple Regulated Activities must pay the highest relevant supervision fee, with each additional Regulated Activity incurring an additional annual supervision fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the fee associated with that Regulated Activity [#P:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6].
question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay both a $10,000 and a $100,000 fee to the Regulator?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative if it is provided by a Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9 [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. For CR Exposure to qualifying MDBs, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight. The qualifying MDBs include entities such as The World Bank Group, the Asian Development Bank, and the African Development Bank, among others [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) of a Credit Derivative provided by a Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) if the MDB is referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9 [#P:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. The risk weight applied to Credit Exposure (CR Exposure) to such MDBs depends on their credit quality grade. Specifically, MDB asset class exposures are risk-weighted at 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1, 50% for Grades 2, 3, and Unrated, 100% for Grades 4 and 5, and 150% for Grade 6 [#P:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]. However, a 0% risk weight must be applied to any CR Exposure to specific MDBs, including the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, or the European Commission [#P:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. Recognition of CRM for a Credit Derivative is permissible provided the transaction meets the conditions set out in Section 4.13, which includes the Credit Derivative being an instrument included in Rule 4.13.11 [#P:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3].
question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB, and what risk weight must be applied to CR Exposure to such MDBs?

gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person can agree with a Third Party Provider in writing to not follow certain rules, like those about charges or consent withdrawal [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If a transaction is disputed, the Third Party Provider must prove it was properly authorized, recorded, and processed, and that there were no technical issues or service problems [#TGT:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92].
pred_answer:
A Customer and a Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain rules will not apply, specifically when the Customer is not a Natural Person. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] These non-applicable rules include those concerning charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Additionally, parties can agree on a different time period for unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for refund requests. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]

If a Customer disputes a Third Party Transaction by denying authorization or claiming incorrect execution, the Third Party Provider bears the burden of proof. [#P:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92] The Provider must demonstrate that the transaction was authenticated, accurately recorded, processed according to its procedures, and was not affected by any technical breakdown or service deficiency, whether by the Provider or any third party it relies upon. [#P:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92] This obligation to prove authentication and execution does not apply if the Customer is not a Natural Person and the parties have agreed in writing that Rule 20.11.1 (evidence on authentication and execution) does not apply. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]
question: When can a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree not to follow some rules, and what must the Provider prove if a transaction is disputed?

gold_answer: The Guidance under section 15(2) of the FSMR is meant to be used with the FSMR, FSRA Rulebooks, and other guidance documents like the ICO Guidance and Virtual Asset Guidance [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537]. Although it provides direction, it is non-binding, meaning it doesn't have legal force and may include notes to the Rules or other guidance not part of the Rules [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd].
pred_answer: The provided context passages do not contain information explaining what it means for Guidance issued under section 15(2) of the FSMR to be non-binding, nor do they detail how such Guidance should be used with other documents beyond stating that it should be read in conjunction with specific regulations and rulebooks. However, the passages consistently indicate that Guidance issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 ("FSMR") is intended to be read alongside the FSMR itself, the relevant Rulebooks of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority ("FSRA"), and the FSRA's Guidance & Policies Manual ("GPM") [#P:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537, #P:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f, #P:5c24d86a-54c9-4d5a-8f45-f4de5f2851fb, #P:e8c08de4-fa9b-4f3f-8377-cfeb054d52b1, #P:f6ab2eab-91b3-43c8-b241-6c146cf50897, #P:252a393e-8698-4378-b189-144a7904a9a6, #P:ec05d9fb-0199-4787-811d-b74021d70efa, #P:19eb0406-621a-4302-aea9-c8dba477a672, #P:e1fbb7b7-d70d-4a40-87c0-ca077ad05b67]. In some instances, specific guidance documents are also mentioned as companions, such as the 'Guidance  Regulation of Digital Security Offerings (ICOs) and Virtual Assets under the FSMR' and the 'Guidance  Regulation of Virtual
question: What does it mean that the Guidance under section 15(2) of the FSMR is non-binding, and how should it be used with other documents?

gold_answer: When an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, they are required to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. In this context, if the Prospectus contains misleading or deceptive statements or omissions, the Issuer may potentially rely on a defence of reasonable reliance on information provided by another person [#TGT:c2dbe9d1-7386-4961-a367-1be69f10e457]. This defence could be applicable if the Issuer can demonstrate that they reasonably relied on the information given by another party when preparing the Prospectus. However, the Issuer must ensure that such reliance was indeed reasonable under the circumstances, as failing to do so could undermine the defence. The interaction between these requirements highlights the importance of due diligence and verification of information used in the Prospectus to avoid potential liabilities.
pred_answer: An Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM is generally obligated to publish an Approved Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR, unless the offer qualifies as an Exempt Offer or Exempt Securities. [#P:1, #P:9] However, Section 70(1) of the FSMR provides a defence against liability for loss caused by a statement or omission in a Prospectus, if certain conditions regarding reasonable reliance on information provided by another person are met. [#P:8] This defence is available if, prior to the acquisition of Securities, a correction to the erroneous statement or omission was published in a manner designed to reach potential acquirers, or if the Issuer took all reasonable steps to secure such publication and reasonably believed it had occurred. [#P:8] This mechanism allows for a potential defence against liability by demonstrating due diligence in correcting or ensuring the accuracy of information presented in a Prospectus, even when relying on third-party input. [#P:8]
question: In the context of an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, how does the requirement to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR interact with the potential defence of reasonable reliance on information provided by another person?

gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1, including those considered commercially sensitive [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the entity deems certain information to be commercially sensitive, it should state this and explain the methodology used to determine these assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Additionally, when issuing a Prospectus within ADGM, the entity must consider section 62(1) of FSMR, which requires the inclusion of all information investors would reasonably require for an informed decision [#TGT:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]. Thus, the entity must balance the need to protect commercially sensitive information with the obligation to provide comprehensive disclosures in a Prospectus.
pred_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity considers material economic assumptions used to determine forecast financial information to be commercially sensitive, it must make a statement to that effect and provide an explanation of the methodology used to determine these assumptions [#P:11.9.2, #P:4]. The entity should also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose sufficient information, potentially in narrative form, to enable investors to understand the methodology and the basis for reporting estimates [#P:3, #P:9]. However, the entity must carefully consider whether this commercially sensitive information needs to be disclosed to meet other obligations, particularly if issuing a Prospectus within ADGM [#P:2, #P:7]. This includes the requirement under section 62(1) of FSMR to include all information investors reasonably require for an informed investment decision, and the requirements under sections 95(2) of FSMR and Rule 7.2.1 to disclose information likely to have a significant effect on the price of financial instruments if generally available [#P:2, #P:7]. Entities should be cautious not to claim information is commercially sensitive if it is not, for instance, if no commercially sensitive contracts underpin assumptions like commodity prices or expenditures [#P:5].
question: In the context of a Mining Reporting Entity's disclosure obligations under Rule 11.9.1, how should commercially sensitive information be handled when it pertains to material economic assumptions, and what considerations apply if the entity is also issuing a Prospectus within ADGM?

gold_answer: Securities in a class admitted to listing and trading, including those pursuant to Rule 4.4.1, must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Regulated Exchange [#SRC:1e1c0168-59f6-439b-bcc2-d705199eeb4a]. However, certain Securities may be exempt from these requirements under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR. These exemptions include, but are not limited to, Shares representing less than 10% of the same class already admitted to trading, Shares issued in substitution without increasing capital, and Securities offered in connection with a Takeover Offer or merger, provided that appropriate documentation is available [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0].
pred_answer: All Securities in a class admitted to listing and trading must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Regulated Exchange [#P:1e1c0168-59f6-439b-bcc2-d705199eeb4a]. Exemptions under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR, which prescribe types of Exempt Securities, mean that these specific securities do not require a Prospectus [#P:63c6805e-92e4-4c6d-b742-c547b94768fe]. The prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR, which generally requires an Approved Prospectus for securities to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, does not apply to these Exempt Securities, subject to Rule 4.4.2 [#P:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. These Exempt Securities include shares representing less than 10% of the same class over 12 months, shares issued in substitution without increasing issued capital, securities offered in connection with a takeover offer or merger where equivalent information is available, securities in a rights issue or free share offer to existing shareholders if certain conditions are met, securities offered to directors or employees under specific conditions, shares from conversion or exchange of other securities, securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange for over 18 months with ongoing obligations met and a summary document approved by the Regulator, and securities offered in connection with specific issues under Rules 9.7.1 or 9.7.4 [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. Similarly, for Units, all Units in a class admitted to trading, including those specified under Rule 3.3.5, must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange [#P:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab]. Exempt offers in respect of Units, which do not require a Prospectus, include Units representing less than 10% of the same class over 12 months, Units issued in substitution without increasing issued
question: Under what conditions must Securities in a class admitted to listing and trading be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and how do exemptions under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR apply?

gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must fill out MKT Form 10-1 every quarter if the Regulator requires it for listing, classifies the entity as a Mining or Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or demands it under section 84 of the FSMR [#SRC:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]. The Regulator's power to set or change conditions for listing can affect this requirement, as these conditions might include the need to complete the form [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b].
pred_answer: A Reporting Entity is required to complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis under specific conditions set by the Regulator. [#P:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] These conditions include situations where the Regulator mandates this reporting as a condition of admission to the Official List, as permitted by section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR. [#P:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Furthermore, a Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 quarterly if it is classified as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity. [#P:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] The Regulator can also require this form pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR. [#P:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Once required to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1), the Reporting Entity must disclose its completed MKT Form 10-1 immediately upon the information becoming available, and no later than one month after the end of each financial quarter. [#P:4f8713d6-2027-436d-a392-2684ec2e2ec8] This applies to both Mining Exploration Reporting Entities [#P:425f10ba-b59e-463a-b2d6-c4995e8597e0] and Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. [#P:ff82a0ec-8ab5-4f3a-b5c5-8d030a85b4fc] The Regulator's power to set listing conditions directly influences this obligation, as it can be a prerequisite for a company to be admitted to the Official List. [#P:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]
question: When does a Reporting Entity have to fill out MKT Form 10-1 every quarter, and how can the Regulator's power to set conditions for listing affect this?

gold_answer: The portion due of the annual designation fee should be calculated based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year, as specified in Rule 1.2.2 for Rule 10.2.1(a) [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f]. The initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date on which the fee becomes due, prorated for the remainder of the calendar year [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. Subsequent annual fees for the period commencing 1 January are payable in advance and must be paid in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37].
pred_answer: The portion of the annual designation fee due, when prorated for the remainder of the calendar year, is calculated based on the number of months left until the end of that year [#P:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f, #P:d45ce4d2-988c-4a8a-9f45-ac2a6d11b08f, #P:cc25dcfa-a71c-4784-b694-9e305d7dee51]. The initial annual designation fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date it becomes due, prorated for the remainder of the calendar year [#P:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. For subsequent calendar years, the annual designation fee of $2,000 is payable in full to the Regulator on or before January 31st of the calendar year to which the fee relates [#P:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]. If a fee is not paid in full by the due date or within the prescribed period, a late payment fee is incurred, which is the greater of $2,000 or 3% of the fee due, with an additional 1% increase for each calendar month or part thereof that the fee remains outstanding [#P:cc25dcfa-a71c-4784-b694-9e305d7dee51].
question: How should the portion due of the annual designation fee be calculated and paid when it is based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year, and what are the payment deadlines for both initial and subsequent annual fees?

gold_answer: Issuers should think about getting legal help when they prepare and submit diligence materials to the FSRA, especially for submissions under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR [#SRC:435adc16-73d0-41c5-bf4d-6aa89e654a45]. The Regulator can send a written notice to either exclude certain requirements or decide that an investment not usually seen as a Security is treated as one for these Regulations [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. This decision is based on terms and conditions the Regulator thinks are right, which can affect how Issuers prepare their submissions.
pred_answer: Issuers should seek legal assistance for FSRA submissions when dealing with digital securities, particularly when preparing and submitting diligence materials for FSRA review under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR, or when making an Offer of Digital Securities. [#P:435adc16-73d0-41c5-bf4d-6aa89e654a45, #P:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] Legal advisers are expected to possess the appropriate skills and knowledge to aid in ensuring compliance with applicable provisions of FSMR and MKT, including assisting the FSRA in deeming a digital security a security. [#P:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The FSRA generally anticipates direct engagement with an Issuer's legal advisers throughout this process, especially concerning the drafting and review of Offer documentation. [#P:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] Regarding investment classifications, the provided context does not contain information on what the Regulator can do about investment classifications. However, the FSRA does monitor developments in virtual tokens and virtual assets and may issue further guidance to update its regulatory framework and ensure it remains risk-appropriate for financial technology innovations. [#P:dfd3f6de-b6dc-4625-9736-77152e4d446a]
question: When should Issuers get legal help for FSRA submissions, and what can the Regulator do about investment classifications?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, or 5 should calculate its Financial Group Capital Resources by using either the accounting consolidation method or the aggregation method, while excluding certain amounts as per Rule 8.3.5 [#SRC:9d34dc36-6eab-454f-9c48-63bd5ab3b3af]. The Authorised Person cannot include Capital Resources from subsidiaries or participations if these resources are more than the entity requirement under Rule 8.3.3 or if they cannot be freely moved within the Financial Group [#TGT:e0096bb2-da49-4bde-84a1-cdbe953d165f].
pred_answer:
An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, or 5 must calculate its Financial Group Capital Resources by applying either the accounting consolidation method, which uses the Financial Group's consolidated financial statements, or the aggregation method. [#P:13] The aggregation method involves summing the Capital Resources of the Parent, the Capital Resources of other Authorised Persons and Financial Institutions within the Financial Group, and the Financial Group's proportionate share of Capital Resources in Financial Institutions where it has a participation but which are not otherwise included in the Financial Group. [#P:13]

An Authorised Person cannot include Capital Resources or Adjusted Capital Resources of subsidiaries or participations if these resources exceed the entity requirement for that subsidiary or participation, calculated according to Rule 8.3.3, and if they are not freely transferable within the Financial Group. [#P:13, #P:8] This exclusion applies to the extent that these conditions are met. [#P:13, #P:8] Furthermore, when determining qualifying Capital Resources of a subsidiary included in consolidated Capital Resources, specific subtractions are required based on the subsidiary's solo capital requirements and its share of the Financial Group's consolidated requirements, as well as its qualifying Capital Resources expressed as a percentage of its total capital instruments and retained earnings. [#P:3] Similarly, qualifying Capital Resources instruments included in consolidated Tier 2 Capital are determined by subtracting the subsidiary's qualifying Tier 1 Capital included in the consolidated Tier 1 Capital of the Financial Group from its qualifying Capital Resources included in the consolidated Capital Resources. [#P:6]
question: How should an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, or 5 work out its Financial Group Capital Resources, and when can't it count resources from subsidiaries?

gold_answer: The requirements in Rule 4.12.1 concerning advertisements do not apply to communications related to the Offer of Securities when such communications fall under specific exclusions. These exclusions include communications made in connection with the trading of Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange, as well as communications made for the purpose of complying with ongoing reporting requirements of a Recognised Investment Exchange or the Regulator [#SRC:53839ad9-8f67-41e3-8914-6b2a71d0975f]. Additionally, communications that are defined as Exempt Communications in Rule 4.2.1 are also excluded from these requirements [#SRC:53839ad9-8f67-41e3-8914-6b2a71d0975f]. These exclusions align with the definition of an Offer of Securities, which also excludes communications related to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange and those made for ongoing reporting compliance [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].
pred_answer: The requirements relating to advertisements in Rule 4.12.1 do not apply to certain communications concerning the Offer of Securities, primarily due to definitional exclusions within the FSMR and specific exemptions outlined in the Rules. These exclusions are applicable to communications made in connection with the trading of Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange, or those made to comply with ongoing reporting requirements of a Recognised Investment Exchange or the Regulator. [#P:53839ad9-8f67-41e3-8914-6b2a71d0975f] Additionally, any communication defined as an "Exempt Communication" under Rule 4.2.1 is also excluded from the advertisement requirements. [#P:53839ad9-8f67-41e3-8914-6b2a71d0975f] Exempt Communications are specifically defined as not being Offers of Securities and therefore do not attract Prospectus requirements. [#P:0b2b84b1-eea1-4dc0-a5b7-70b68bc88ad4] Furthermore, the definition of an Offer of Securities itself excludes communications made in connection with the trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, communications for ongoing reporting requirements, or other communications prescribed as exempt. [#P:b2818e21-ad91-4fe4-bdae-d5ccee8373b9] The Financial Promotion Restriction, which is related to advertisement requirements, also does not apply to communications that are non-real-time or solicited real-time communications, relate to investments permitted to be traded on a relevant market, and are required or expressly permitted by market rules, a market's regulating body, or a body regulating offers of investments for such markets. [#P:b2818e21-ad91-4fe4-bdae-d5ccee8373b9]
question: Under what circumstances do the requirements in Rule 4.12.1 regarding advertisements not apply to communications related to the Offer of Securities?

gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must include all important economic assumptions and other material assumptions when sharing financial forecasts [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If any assumptions are sensitive, the entity should say so and explain how they were determined [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. For Ore Reserves, the entity needs to do a Technical Study, like a feasibility study, and share the main assumptions and results [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. This helps ensure all necessary information is clear and complete.
pred_answer:
When a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include the Production Target itself, along with all information contained in Rule 11.8.3 [#P:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. This disclosure must detail all material economic assumptions employed, or if these are considered commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect with an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, alongside all other material assumptions utilized [#P:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If forecast commodity prices were used, a statement confirming they were arrived at on reasonable grounds is required [#P:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. The entity must also specify the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and Exploration Targets, including specific statements if Inferred Mineral Resources or Exploration Targets are not the determining factors in project viability or are not significant in the early mine plan [#P:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].

If a Mining Reporting Entity relies on guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a) regarding Ore Reserves, it must state that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, explain why this information is considered sensitive, and disclose sufficient information about the methodology used to determine these factors and assumptions, even if in narrative form [#P:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]. It is important to note that information about commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions may be difficult to claim as commercially sensitive if not underpinned by actual commercially sensitive contracts [#P:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Forecast financial information can be disclosed in relation to Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or material Mining Projects [#P:3b6fe7
question: What must a Mining Reporting Entity include when sharing financial forecasts and Ore Reserves, especially if some details are sensitive?

gold_answer: The Regulator may refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it determines that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation, or if it has reasonable grounds to believe that they may not comply in the future [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. Additionally, the Regulator may also choose not to transmit the notice if it considers it necessary and appropriate to further one or more of its objectives [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. This decision must be made within the context of the requirement to provide notice of intent to use passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days of receiving the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2, as stipulated in the TARGET passage [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7].
pred_answer: The Regulator may refrain from transmitting a notice of intent to use passporting procedures under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if there are reasonable grounds to believe they may not comply in the future. Additionally, the Regulator may choose not to transmit the notice if it deems it necessary and appropriate to do so in order to further one or more of its objectives. These conditions are outlined in Rule 3.1.5, which provides the grounds for the Regulator to withhold the transmission of the notice, even though the general requirement is to provide such notice within five Business Days of receiving the initial notification from the Fund Manager of a Private Fund wishing to use passporting procedures. [#P:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c, #P:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7, #P:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb]
question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) despite the requirement to provide notice of intent to use passporting procedures within five Business Days?

gold_answer: A Domestic Firm must always have enough Capital Resources to meet its Capital Requirement [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e]. It needs systems and controls to check this regularly [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79]. If these checks show it might not meet the requirement, the firm must tell the Regulator right away [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79].
pred_answer: A Domestic Firm must ensure its Capital Resources at all times equal or exceed its Capital Requirement, and must also maintain additional capital and liquid assets adequate for its business's nature, size, and complexity to prevent liabilities from falling due unmet [#P:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e, #P:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. If the Governing Body assesses that the required Capital Resources do not adequately reflect the business's nature and risks, the firm should maintain additional resources [#P:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d]. While not required to measure capital precisely daily, an Insurer (which may include a Domestic Firm) must be able to demonstrate its capital adequacy upon request by the Regulator [#P:c6b8d4e9-f326-4f13-b663-155e9140e81f]. The firm must have and maintain Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified and calculated according to the Rules [#P:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].
question: What must a Domestic Firm do to make sure it has enough capital, and what should it do if it thinks it won't?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee if it is provided by a multilateral development bank (MDB) referred to in Rule 4.12.8 [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d]. For any CR Exposure to the qualifying MDBs, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. This applies to MDBs such as the World Bank Group, the Asian Development Bank, and others listed in the relevant rule [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of credit risk mitigation (CRM) of a guarantee provided by a Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) if the MDB is referred to in Rule 4.12.8 and meets the requirements for eligible guarantors under Section 4.13.9. [#P:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] Specifically, for CR Exposures to qualifying MDBs, an Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight. [#P:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] These qualifying MDBs include the World Bank Group (comprising IBRD, MIGA, and IFC), the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the African Development Bank (AfDB), the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), the Inter American Development Bank (IADB), the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Investment Fund (EIF), the Nordic Investment Bank (NIB), the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB), the Islamic Development Bank (IDB), and the Council of Europe Development Bank (CEDB). [#P:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] Furthermore, if a guarantee meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, the Authorised Person may treat the portion of the Exposure which is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party providing the guarantee, rather than to the original client. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] It is crucial that there is no Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure when considering such a guarantee. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]
question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person recognise the effects of credit risk mitigation (CRM) of a guarantee provided by a multilateral development bank (MDB), and what risk weight must be applied to any CR Exposure to qualifying MDBs?

gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must include in its quarterly report details of its activities and those of its controlled entities, if applicable, related to Petroleum Exploration, production, and development, or state if there were no such activities [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. The report should also summarize any related expenditures and list the Petroleum Tenements held, acquired, or disposed of during the quarter, including their locations and percentage interests [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. This report must be submitted no later than one month after the end of the quarter [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1].
pred_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose a quarterly report containing specific details regarding its petroleum activities and holdings, and this report is due no later than one month after the end of each financial quarter. [#P:12.13.1, #P:12.13.3] The report must include details of exploration activities, or a statement that none occurred, and similarly for production and development activities. [#P:12.13.1, #P:10.1.3B.(1)] Additionally, it requires a summary of all expenditure incurred in relation to both exploration and production/development activities. [#P:12.13.1, #P:10.1.3B.(1)] The entity must also list the Petroleum Tenements held at the quarter's end, including their location and the percentage interest held, along with beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements. [#P:12.13.1, #P:10.1.3B.(1)] Any Petroleum Tenements or beneficial interests acquired or disposed of during the quarter, and their locations, must also be detailed. [#P:12.13.1] Furthermore, at least once every 12 months, a Summary of Reserves and Resources, as required by Rule 12.14.1, must be included, unless it is already part of the entity's annual report, and the report must specify when the previous and upcoming disclosures of this summary were or will be made. [#P:12.13.1]
question: What must a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity include in its quarterly report, and when is it due?

gold_answer: A Relevant Person is required to immediately provide records to the Regulator upon request, or to a law enforcement agency pursuant to a valid and enforceable request or requirement [#SRC:c96c05de-76d2-4f05-b2ea-6f4fb9615094]. The types of records that must be maintained include documents and information obtained during initial and ongoing customer due diligence, records related to customer business relationships such as business correspondence and transaction records, internal findings on unusual or suspicious transactions, internal notifications of suspicious activity, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports, communications with the Financial Intelligence Unit, and any other records expressly required under the Rules [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. These records must be kept for at least six years from the date of the notification, the end of the business relationship, or the completion of the transaction, whichever is later [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98].
pred_answer: A Relevant Person must provide records to the Regulator or a law enforcement agency immediately upon request or pursuant to a valid and enforceable request, respectively [#P:c96c05de-76d2-4f05-b2ea-6f4fb9615094]. The specific types of records that must be maintained for potential provision are extensive and include, but are not limited to, documents and information obtained during initial and ongoing Customer Due Diligence (CDD) or due diligence on business partners [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. Additionally, records pertaining to customer business relationships, such as business correspondence, transaction details enabling reconstruction, and internal findings on unusual or suspicious activities, must be kept [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. This also encompasses internal notifications of suspicious activity, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting documents, communications with the FIU, and any other matters expressly required by the Rules [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. These records must generally be maintained for at least six years from the date of notification, report, end of the business relationship, or completion of a transaction, whichever is latest [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. If records are kept outside the ADGM, reasonable steps must be taken to ensure they are held consistently with the Rules, easily accessible, and immediately available for inspection upon the Regulator's request [#P:1c5a2e03-760c-4263-88bd-eb100e0368b4]. Furthermore, Relevant Persons must identify any secrecy or data protection legislation that might restrict access and obtain certified copies of relevant records, keeping them in a jurisdiction that allows access [#P:9ec361b2-cc02-48d4-a3f0-9c358cf6394e].
question: Under what circumstances must a Relevant Person provide records to the Regulator or a law enforcement agency, and what specific types of records must be maintained for potential provision?

gold_answer: T2 Capital is composed of the sum of specific elements, including capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria outlined in Rule 3.12.3 and the associated Share premium accounts [#TGT:2ba8da20-d967-4d1e-bf49-877f5e6ceddb]. However, the final calculation of T2 Capital is subject to deductions as stipulated later in the Section, which may reduce the total sum of these elements [#SRC:50484f09-d585-4330-9505-ba858c7d09c6].
pred_answer: Tier 2 (T2) Capital is calculated as the sum of specific elements, primarily capital instruments meeting eligibility criteria and related share premium accounts, subject to certain deductions outlined later in the Section. [#P:13] [#P:6] These deductions are crucial for accurately determining the T2 Capital amount. [#P:1] An Authorised Person must deduct direct and indirect holdings of their own T2 Capital instruments, including those they are contractually obliged to purchase. [#P:3] Additionally, holdings of T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be deducted if there is a reciprocal cross-holding that artificially inflates capital resources, or if the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities. [#P:3] Holdings of T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment are also deducted, with an exclusion for underwriting positions held for fewer than five working days. [#P:3] Furthermore, any amounts required to be deducted from T2 Capital that exceed the Authorised Person's T2 Capital must be deducted from AT1 Capital. [#P:5] An exclusion from T2 Capital applies to firms managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account, where specific reserves exceeding the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement are excluded. [#P:7] [#P:10]
question: What elements constitute T2 Capital, and how do the deductions later in the Section affect its calculation?

gold_answer: The Regulator can ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee if the Controller is from a place without a proper agreement with the Regulator, or if they want to change the business model, activities, or senior managers of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. More money can also be required if the application is very complex and needs extra work or costs [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. The $1,000 fee is for applying for a new Controller or a change in Holding [#TGT:db5cfcd0-4783-4652-b75b-d9eee44a9873].
pred_answer: The Regulator may request a supplementary fee in addition to the standard $1,000 application fee for a new Controller or a change in an existing Controller's Holding under specific circumstances. [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df] These circumstances include situations where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the Controller's jurisdiction. [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df] Additionally, a supplementary fee may be charged if the Controller's application involves changes to the business model, business activities, or senior management of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body. [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df] Furthermore, the Regulator reserves the right to impose a supplementary fee if the application's complexity necessitates substantial additional expense or effort from the Regulator. [#P:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df] These situations arise when an Authorised Person or Recognised Body is applying for written approval of a proposed new Controller or a change in the Holding of an existing Controller that triggers the requirement to seek the Regulator's approval. [#P:db5cfcd0-4783-4652-b75b-d9eee44a9873]
question: When can the Regulator ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee for a new Controller or change in Holding?

gold_answer: A Captive Insurer must comply with a collateral notice issued by the Regulator, which mandates the availability of assets of a specified type and manner as described in Rule 10.3.2(5) [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. The value of these assets is determined as the lesser of the amount specified in the notice and the amount calculated in accordance with Rule 10.3.2(4) [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7].
