For a Captive Insurer, the amount under Rule 10.3.2(4) is calculated based on the sum of its Insurance Liabilities and the minimum capital requirement as provided in Rule 2.2, unless specific conditions in Rule 10.3.2(4)(a) or Rule 10.3.2(4)(d) apply [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39]. This ensures that the Captive Insurer maintains sufficient assets to meet regulatory requirements.
pred_answer: A Captive Insurer must comply with a collateral notice requiring asset availability when issued by the Regulator, which may be varied or revoked at any time by written notice [#P:5a7d84a5-f46a-4936-ab4d-1afdf2362f87]. The assets must be of a type and in a manner described in Rule 10.3.2(5) [#P:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. The value of these assets is determined as the lower of the amount specified in the collateral notice or the amount calculated according to Rule 10.3.2(4) [#P:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. When Rule 10.3.2(4) is applicable, the amount is calculated based on the specific structure of the Captive Insurer. For a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, it is the sum of Insurance Liabilities attributable to that cell and the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement for that cell [#P:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39(a)]. For a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it is the sum of Insurance Liabilities attributable to the fund and the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement for the fund, subject to specific sub-rules [#P:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39(b)]. For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, it is the sum of the Captive Insurer's Insurance Liabilities and its minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2 [#P:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39(c)]. If a reassessment shows that the assets made available are less than required, the Captive Insurer must provide additional assets within two months of the reassessment's effective date to comply with the collateral notice [#P:663
question: Under what circumstances must a Captive Insurer comply with a collateral notice requiring asset availability, and how is the amount determined when both Rule 10.3.2(4) and Rule 10.3.2(5) are applicable?

gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must ensure that no one else has any interest in or rights over the Relevant Money in a Payment Account, except as allowed by the rules [#SRC:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca]. The account must be clearly marked to show it is for safeguarding Relevant Money according to Chapter 14 [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. It should only be used for Payment Transactions and for holding Relevant Money [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520].
pred_answer: A Payment Service Provider must ensure that no other party holds any interest in or right over Relevant Money held in a Payment Account, except as stipulated by the Rules. [#P:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca] To achieve this, the Payment Account must be designated to clearly demonstrate its purpose of safeguarding Relevant Money in accordance with Chapter 14 of the Rules. [#P:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520] Furthermore, the account must be exclusively used for holding Relevant Money and for no other purpose than in relation to Payment Transactions. [#P:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520] Payment Service Providers are also prohibited from accepting or distributing physical cash, and must safeguard all Relevant Money placed in Payment Accounts. [#P:4b86169a-20a4-4c56-91de-63c79ec98663] This safeguarding obligation extends to money retained in a Payment Account or held in a segregated manner for the redemption of Stored Value. [#P:28899ab4-d64c-4f97-9055-404ed26793c4] Relevant Money must be treated similarly to Client Money for segregation and distribution purposes following a Pooling Event, with distribution occurring either based on Payment Service User balances or for Stored Value redemption. [#P:c023c656-8826-475f-ba8c-0eb4750d08d7]
question: How should a Payment Service Provider make sure no one else has rights over Relevant Money in a Payment Account, and what should the account be used for?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person needs to check if its capital instruments meet the rules for eligibility under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2 to include them in Available Stable Funding, but it must leave out any Tier 2 capital instruments that have less than one year left until they mature [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. Tier 2 Capital includes instruments that meet Rule 3.12.3 and their related Share premium accounts [#TGT:2ba8da20-d967-4d1e-bf49-877f5e6ceddb]. So, the Authorised Person must follow these rules and exclusions when deciding.
pred_answer: To determine which capital instruments are included in Available Stable Funding (ASF), an Authorised Person must identify eligible capital instruments by considering those that meet the requirements of Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2 [#P:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. Specifically for Tier 2 capital instruments, all such instruments with a residual maturity of less than one year must be excluded from this consideration [#P:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. Tier 2 capital is defined as "gone concern" capital that ensures depositors and senior creditors can be repaid in the event of an Authorised Person's failure, thereby enabling the continuation of activities and prevention of insolvency [#P:80734ead-ac3f-4fd5-8f69-ba0fb46099c5]. Additionally, an Authorised Person must include in its ASF calculation the total amount of other capital instruments not captured under Rule A10.4.2 that have a residual maturity of one year or more [#P:962a8544-78bb-4ee4-ab0f-8f803908e889]. When determining the residual maturity of any instrument or liability included in ASF, the Authorised Person must calculate it as the period up to the earliest point at which an investor can exercise their right to redeem their investment or withdraw funding [#P:68a2eabe-76b5-4a9c-8bad-d8c20fd492aa]. Investors should be assumed to redeem a call option at the earliest possible date available to them when determining maturity, though the Regulator may consider reputational factors limiting an Authorised Person's ability not to exercise an option [#P:5cbfc8ca-97f6-4a2f-ba8e-5ea1543be6d3].
question: What should an Authorised Person do to decide which capital instruments go into Available Stable Funding, and what about Tier 2 capital?

gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must make sure that there are satisfactory arrangements for settling the rights and liabilities of parties involved in transactions on the exchange [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. These arrangements should follow the requirements mentioned in Rule 4.3.3, as referenced by Rule 3.8.1 [#SRC:549c69d5-2c89-4747-8878-9ae4ce57346e].
pred_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place for securing the timely discharge, whether by performance, compromise, or otherwise, of the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of parties involved in transactions executed on the exchange. [#P:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616] If the Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party for clearing services that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it is further obligated to confirm in writing to the Regulator that these satisfactory arrangements, as stipulated under Rule 3.8.1, have been made. [#P:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] These arrangements are crucial for ensuring that all rights and liabilities stemming from transactions are cleared and settled promptly and effectively. [#P:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]
question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service, what must they do to make sure everything is settled on time, according to Rule 3.8.1?

gold_answer: A person can justify their conduct as legitimate if they can establish that their actions were carried out for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]. This justification is necessary when the behaviour involves effecting transactions or orders to trade that might otherwise give a false or misleading impression regarding the supply, demand, or price of Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities, or secure their price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].
pred_answer: A person may justify conduct that might otherwise create a false or misleading impression or secure an artificial price level if it is undertaken for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market [#P:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f, #P:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b]. Such conduct is considered legitimate if it is not intended to create a false or misleading impression, or if it is undertaken for the purpose of stabilising the price of investments in conformity with Price Stabilisation Rules, or in conformity with Control of Information Rules [#P:57e0f3ff-72ca-4b4b-a4c9-523da64bbf49]. Furthermore, specific defences may apply, including participation in a liquidity scheme operated by a Recognised Investment Exchange, legitimate performance of an underwriting agreement, or acting in the course of functions as a liquidator or receiver [#P:c685f24d-b033-4abc-9af1-8c5399ef11a5]. Other justifications include acting solely as a market maker, executing an unsolicited client order without advising on the transaction, engaging in a takeover bid for control or merger purposes, or acquiring own shares for legitimate share capital reduction or redemption [#P:c685f24d-b033-4abc-9af1-8c5399ef11a5]. The conduct must not be for the purpose of inducing others to trade or to move the price of a financial instrument [#P:6a6b8b06-6a6b-4399-8f9e-d130e8a62cbc].
question: Under what conditions can a person justify their conduct as legitimate when effecting transactions that might otherwise give a misleading impression or secure an artificial price level?

gold_answer: Before paying Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, an Authorised Person must assess the suitability of the Third-Party Agent and conclude that they are suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. The Authorised Person must include records of this assessment and the Third-Party Agent's acknowledgement regarding Client Money in their Resolution Pack, as specified in Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].
pred_answer: Before an Authorised Person pays Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, it must first conduct a thorough assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent, concluding on reasonable grounds that the agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#P:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143]. Subsequently, the Authorised Person must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent confirming that all funds in the account are held on behalf of its clients and that the Third-Party Agent cannot combine the account with any other or exercise any charges or liens against the funds for sums owed by the Authorised Person [#P:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9]. The Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include records pertaining to these actions, specifically referencing Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4, which cover the assessment of the Third-Party Agent's appropriateness and the required acknowledgment concerning Client Money [#P:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Additionally, the Resolution Pack must contain a document identifying all institutions appointed to hold Client Accounts for Client Money, as well as copies of executed agreements between the Authorised Person and each identified third party that relate to the holding of Client Money [#P:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. The pack also requires the most recent reconciliations of Client Money held with Third Party Agents [#P:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].
question: What must an Authorised Person do before paying Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, and what records about this must be in their Resolution Pack?

gold_answer: The Regulator assesses whether a document related to Exempt Securities under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR contains all relevant information by considering the requirements outlined in Part 6 of the FSMR and the Rules in the chapter [#SRC:28df1695-9376-47bf-921d-e9cbd61c7b30]. This evaluation is crucial for Securities such as those offered in connection with a Takeover Offer or a merger, where a document must be available containing information equivalent to that of a Prospectus [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. The Regulator's determination ensures that the document meets the necessary informational standards for these specific types of Securities.
pred_answer: The Regulator determines whether a document related to Exempt Securities under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR contains all relevant information by considering the information required under Part 6 of the FSMR and the Rules in the relevant chapter. [#P:28df1695-9376-47bf-921d-e9cbd61c7b30] Specifically, for securities to be considered Exempt Securities, the Regulator prescribes various types, such as shares representing less than 10% of the number of shares of the same class already admitted to trading over 12 months, or shares issued in substitution without increasing issued capital. [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] Additionally, securities offered in connection with takeovers, mergers, or rights issues may be considered Exempt Securities if a document is available containing information deemed by the Regulator to be equivalent to a Prospectus. [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] For certain exemptions, such as those involving securities admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange, a summary document in English, approved by the Regulator, must be published, containing specific information and indicating where the most recent Prospectus and ongoing financial information can be obtained. [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] The Regulator's assessment will take into account the information required by both the FSMR and the specific Rules governing these exemptions. [#P:28df1695-9376-47bf-921d-e9cbd61c7b30]
question: How does the Regulator determine whether a document related to Exempt Securities under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR contains all the relevant information, considering the requirements of Part 6 of the FSMR and the Rules in the chapter?

gold_answer: A Third Party Provider has to refund for an unauthorised transaction once it confirms that the transaction was not authorised or was executed incorrectly [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. This refund should happen as soon as possible, but no later than the end of the next day after confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. The refund must be given to the Primary Financial Institution for any amount it already refunded to the Customer, and to the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised transaction, minus any refund already given to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe].
pred_answer: A Third Party Provider must refund for an unauthorised Third Party Transaction as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed [#P:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. The refund is provided to the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount the Third Party Provider has already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. Additionally, the Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount that institution may have already refunded to the Customer [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. This refund obligation does not apply if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer [#P:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. Furthermore, a Customer is only entitled to redress if they notify their Third Party Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the date of execution, upon becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction [#P:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. The Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and Customer should also detail the conditions for the payment of any refund to the Customer [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
question: When does a Third Party Provider have to refund for an unauthorised transaction, and who gets the refund?

gold_answer: The Regulator can revoke a Recognition Order for a Recognised Body or Remote Body if the body involved either asks for it or agrees to it [#TGT:3ef78fff-df9e-4b9b-b709-a575f953bbda]. This action is allowed under section 134(1) of FSMR, which requires the consent of the relevant body for revocation [#SRC:62908d5d-eb70-4217-a2b5-520be929d63f].
pred_answer: A Recognition Order for a Recognised Body or Remote Body can be revoked by the Regulator under several circumstances, with the consent of the body in question being a significant factor. The Regulator may revoke an order at the request or with the consent of the Recognised Body or Remote Body concerned. [#P:3ef78fff-df9e-4b9b-b709-a575f953bbda, #P:62908d5d-eb70-4217-a2b5-520be929d63f] Additionally, the Regulator has the power to revoke a Recognition Order if it appears that a Recognised Body or Remote Body is failing or has failed to satisfy the applicable Recognition Requirements or Remote Recognition Requirements, or has failed to comply with any other obligation imposed on it by or under the Regulations. [#P:b2b5ba50-2f03-42e2-8137-016352e4a555, #P:031687c8-8b78-4189-b979-af424d25b3ad] The Regulator will usually consider revoking an order if the Recognised Body is failing to meet Recognition Requirements with serious consequences, if compliance with a direction under the Regulator's power is not possible, if it would be inappropriate to give such a direction, or if the Recognised Body has not carried on business for a specified period after the order took effect or before revocation. [#P:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] In cases where revocation is not based on the consent of the Recognised Body, the Regulator will typically follow a procedure involving written notice stating the reasons and inviting representations, consideration of those representations, and written notification of the final decision. [#P:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd] Following a revocation, the Regulator may issue directions regarding the continued application of certain provisions. [#P:91841a34-b905-477a-b57f-4b46d4db0ed3
question: When can a Recognition Order be taken back by the Regulator for a Recognised Body or Remote Body, and how does consent matter?

gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should disclose all important economic assumptions for both Production Targets and financial forecasts [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489][#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. If these assumptions are sensitive, the entity must say so and explain how they were determined [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489][#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. This ensures transparency while protecting sensitive information.
pred_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must disclose material economic assumptions used in determining both Production Targets and forecast financial information, with specific procedures if these assumptions are considered commercially sensitive. If material economic assumptions are deemed commercially sensitive, the entity must state this and provide an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, rather than disclosing the assumptions themselves. [#P:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489, #P:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] This includes making a statement to the effect that the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, explaining why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive, and disclosing sufficient information, potentially in narrative form, to enable investors to understand the methodology and basis for reporting estimates. [#P:09aca426-0526-4305-9aa4-12e87c9b3c96] Entities should be cautious not to claim commercial sensitivity without justification, such as the absence of underpinning commercially sensitive contracts for commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions. [#P:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] Guidance on handling commercially sensitive material economic assumptions can be found in specific paragraphs of the Guidance on Mining and Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. [#P:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489, #P:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
question: How should a Mining Reporting Entity disclose sensitive economic assumptions for both Production Targets and financial forecasts?

gold_answer: The Regulator can add Securities to the Official List only if the Securities meet the requirements in the FSMR and the Rulebook [#SRC:0bb34f72-20bd-464f-abe6-89c6c9ad7967]. Before doing so, the Regulator must also decide if the Securities are appropriate according to the rules in this Part [#TGT:507cd713-ca86-4535-8687-25f1305317c6].
pred_answer: The Regulator adds Securities to the Official List when it publishes the admission by adding such Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website. [#P:d28d3376-4af3-4b11-b90d-3f24c8e54555] Before admitting Securities, the Regulator may consider various factors and may impose conditions as it deems appropriate. [#P:fe5c7331-b6e2-4972-994b-f08a54f92181] This includes carrying out enquiries, requesting further information, consulting with other regulators or exchanges, and requiring an Applicant to answer questions or explain relevant matters. [#P:fe5c7331-b6e2-4972-994b-f08a54f92181] The Regulator may also request that provided information be verified in a specified manner and can impose additional conditions on the Applicant. [#P:fe5c7331-b6e2-4972-994b-f08a54f92181] Furthermore, the Regulator may require an Issuer or applicant to appoint a Sponsor for each application for admission or to provide third-party certification regarding specific matters related to the application. [#P:52f54e98-f891-48bc-bfb6-28bdfd75a824] In certain circumstances, the Regulator may modify requirements for an Exempt Offeror who voluntarily seeks to comply with Listing Rules to have its Securities included on the Official List, which is a prerequisite for trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#P:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc] The Regulator is aware that the timing of admission to trading may differ from the admission to the Official List and will generally provide a notice of admission conditional on successful admission to trading within a specified period. [#P:ff616e1c-3923-4cb8-9ba7-fa6c0d149a29]
question: When can the Regulator add Securities to the Official List, and what must they think about first?

gold_answer: A company needs approval from its shareholders to issue more shares if it wants to issue more than 20% of its Base Amount of shares minus any Relevant Issues [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. The Base Amount includes shares issued in the past year if they were approved under Rule 9.7.1 [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Rule 9.7.1 is important because it requires certain share issues to be approved, and these approved issues can be counted in the Base Amount [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295]. This means that getting approval under Rule 9.7.1 can help a company issue more shares without needing further approval.
pred_answer: A company generally requires shareholder approval to issue more shares when the issuance, or agreement to issue, exceeds certain thresholds or involves specific circumstances, as outlined by Rule 9.7.1 and related provisions. Specifically, Rule 9.7.1 mandates that a Listed Entity must not issue or agree to issue more Equity Securities than a calculated limit without the approval of its Ordinary Security holders [#P:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. This limit is determined by a formula involving the "Base Amount" (the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue 12 months prior, plus certain additions and subtractions) and "Relevant Issues" (securities issued or agreed to be issued in the preceding 12 months, excluding those approved under Rule 9.7.1 or 9.7.5, or issued under exceptions in Rule 9.7.4) [#P:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Furthermore, an increase in issued Share capital exceeding 20% of the current Share capital requires shareholder approval, irrespective of whether it falls within the authorized capital [#P:0a089368-eb53-405b-be40-7d5b0410ba36]. Rule 9.7.1 also applies to the issuance of shares as part of a merger or takeover, or in connection with rights issues, unless specific exemptions are met [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. An agreement to issue Equity Securities can be conditional on subsequent shareholder approval under Rule 9.7.1, but the securities must not be issued without such approval [#P:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437]. Importantly, an issue made without prior approval under Rule 9.7.1 can be treated as approved if it did not exceed the limit, was subsequently approved by Ordinary Security holders, and the securities were issued within three months of that approval [#P:3f609871-
question: When does a company need approval from its shareholders to issue more shares, and how does Rule 9.7.1 fit into this?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct goodwill and other intangible assets from its CET1 Capital as defined by the International Financial Reporting Standards [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. The deduction amount for intangible assets must be adjusted by reducing it by the amount of associated deferred tax liabilities that would be extinguished if the intangible assets became impaired or were derecognised [#SRC:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f]. Additionally, the deduction must include goodwill that is part of the valuation of significant investments of the Authorised Person [#SRC:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct goodwill and other intangible assets from its CET1 Capital, subject to specific adjustments for associated deferred tax liabilities and the inclusion of goodwill within significant investments [#P:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. The amount to be deducted for intangible assets must be reduced by the amount of associated deferred tax liabilities that would be extinguished if the intangible assets became impaired or were derecognised under International Financial Reporting Standards [#P:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f]. Conversely, the amount to be deducted must include goodwill that is part of the valuation of the Authorised Person's significant investments [#P:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f]. An investment is considered significant if the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments of the entity, has Close Links and owns CET1 Capital instruments, or owns CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is included in the same accounting consolidation for financial reporting purposes, even if not consolidated under Chapter 8 [#P:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11]. Furthermore, deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability are also subject to deduction, with certain thresholds applying to the aggregate amount of deferred tax assets and holdings in relevant entities that are not deducted [#P:0c37a2eb-9d0d-48ef-97b0-e36655f0794e].
question: How must an Authorised Person account for intangible assets and goodwill in the calculation of CET1 Capital deductions, considering the requirements for deferred tax liabilities and significant investments?

gold_answer: The Regulator must provide the Applicant with a written notice of its decision when deciding on a listing application [#TGT:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c]. This requirement is linked to the process of admitting Securities to the Official List, where the Regulator also needs to notify the Applicant in writing about its decision [#SRC:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e]. Both actions ensure that the Applicant is formally informed of the outcome, maintaining clear communication.
pred_answer: Upon deciding on a listing application, the Regulator must inform the Applicant in writing of its decision. [#P:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e, #P:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c] This notification is a crucial step in the process, as the admission of Securities to the Official List only becomes effective once the Regulator has published the admission by adding such Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website. [#P:d28d3376-4af3-4b11-b90d-3f24c8e54555] In reaching its decision, the Regulator has broad discretion to conduct enquiries, request further information, consult with other regulators, and require explanations or verification of provided information. [#P:fe5c7331-b6e2-4972-994b-f08a54f92181] The Regulator may also impose additional conditions on the Applicant as it deems appropriate. [#P:fe5c7331-b6e2-4972-994b-f08a54f92181] Furthermore, the Regulator may require an applicant to appoint a Sponsor or provide third-party certification in relation to the application. [#P:52f54e98-f891-48bc-bfb6-28bdfd75a824] In practice, the Regulator often provides a notice of admission to the Official List conditional upon successful admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange within a specified timeframe. [#P:ff616e1c-3923-4cb8-9ba7-fa6c0d149a29]
question: When the Regulator decides on a listing application, what must they do to inform the Applicant, and how does this relate to the decision about admitting Securities to the Official List?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must ensure that they only use Accepted Virtual Assets [#TGT:7bed5f55-c0d5-4a97-93d4-3db078c11610]. To comply with Rule 17.2.1, the maturity and market capitalisation requirements for these Virtual Assets are detailed in the Guidance published by the Regulator [#SRC:be581022-abaa-45d4-b047-d79001197dbe].
pred_answer: To ensure compliance with maturity and market capitalisation requirements for Accepted Virtual Assets, an Authorised Person must understand that the Regulator determines whether a Virtual Asset meets these criteria by considering a maturity/market capitalisation threshold and other relevant factors [#P:223a987c-f08a-4402-8d01-2472978dd1e8]. The specific maturity and market capitalisation requirements are detailed in accompanying Guidance published by the Regulator concerning Virtual Assets [#P:be581022-abaa-45d4-b047-d79001197dbe]. The FSRA considers seven key factors when determining if a Virtual Asset is "Accepted," which include maturity, security, traceability/monitoring, exchange connectivity, the type of Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) used, innovation/efficiency, and practical application/functionality [#P:480fd476-0932-4064-b15a-5e2299439911]. An Authorised Person must demonstrate how a Virtual Asset meets these requirements, as a Virtual Asset that meets the FSRA's criteria will only constitute an Accepted Virtual Asset for that specific Authorised Person [#P:480fd476-0932-4064-b15a-5e2299439911]. The Regulator may also prescribe additional requirements for Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities in relation to Virtual Assets [#P:4502513a-7a4f-43dd-b950-b8b78df57e5d].
question: How must an Authorised Person ensure compliance with the maturity and market capitalisation requirements when conducting a Regulated Activity involving Virtual Assets?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Risk Capital Requirement by summing several components, one of which is the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. The CRCOM is specifically governed by the Rules in Part 3, which are further supplemented by App4, detailing the manner of its calculation [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. In addition to the CRCOM, the Risk Capital Requirement includes the Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (where applicable), and the CVA Risk Capital Requirement [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. The comprehensive calculation of these components ensures the Authorised Person meets its overall Capital Requirement obligations as outlined in the Rules [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person must incorporate the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) as a fundamental component in the calculation of its overall Risk Capital Requirement, as stipulated by the relevant Rules and supplemented by App4 [#P:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. The CRCOM is one of several elements that sum to form the total Risk Capital Requirement [#P:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. Specifically, the overall Risk Capital Requirement is calculated as the sum of the CRCOM, the Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (if applicable), and the CVA Risk Capital Requirement [#P:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. The Authorised Person is obligated to calculate its CRCOM in strict accordance with the applicable Rules found in Chapter 4 [#P:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. Furthermore, when determining the CRCOM and Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Authorised Person must also consider the relevant provisions within the IFR rules pertaining to Credit Risk and Market Risk for Islamic Contracts [#P:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. The CRCOM itself is a key element in the calculation of the overall Risk Capital Requirement for an Authorised Person, as outlined in Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2, and its calculation is governed by the Rules in Part 3, along with App4 [#P:cccc600d-2016-48f8-8b11-a8a9ae1aeebc].
question: How must an Authorised Person incorporate the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) into the overall calculation of its Risk Capital Requirement, considering the components outlined in the relevant Rules and the supplementary guidance provided in App4?

gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This agreement allows the parties to set different terms regarding the revocation of Payment Orders, potentially affecting the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction. Normally, the Customer can withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction at any time before it can no longer be revoked as per Rule 20.8.2 [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. However, if Rule 20.8.2 is excluded by agreement, the standard revocation terms may not apply, and the parties may establish alternative conditions for consent withdrawal.
pred_answer: A Customer and a Third Party Provider may agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2 if the Customer is not a Natural Person [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This exclusion impacts the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction by removing the specific rules governing the revocation of a Payment Order [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Consequently, if Rule 20.8.2 is excluded, the ability for a Customer to withdraw consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before it can no longer be revoked, as stipulated in Rule 20.8.2, is no longer applicable [#P:84c622c5-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. Similarly, the ability for a Customer to withdraw consent to a series of Third Party Transactions at any time, which would render previously consented but unexecuted transactions as unauthorized, is also affected by the exclusion of Rule 20.8.2 [#P:e4c92e77-6fe0-46b4-a71f-9f3a479ee273]. The exclusion of Rule 20.8.2 is one of several rules that can be waived by written agreement when the Customer is not a Natural Person [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44].
question: Under what conditions may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2, and how does this affect the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction?

gold_answer: A business customer and a Third Party Provider can agree in writing to ignore the rule about revoking a payment order, which is Rule 20.8.2 [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If they don't make such an agreement, the customer can still withdraw consent for a series of transactions at any time. Any transactions that were agreed to but not yet done when consent is withdrawn will not be considered authorised anymore [#TGT:e4c92e77-6fe0-46b4-a71f-9f3a479ee273].
pred_answer: A business customer and a Third Party Provider can agree in writing that the rule regarding the revocation of a Payment Order does not apply to them. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] If consent to a series of Third Party Transactions is withdrawn, any transactions that have been previously consented to but not yet executed at the time of withdrawal will no longer be considered authorized. [#P:e4c92e77-6fe0-46b4-a71f-9f3a479ee273] This agreement to exclude the rule on revoking a Payment Order is permissible under specific conditions where the customer is not a Natural Person. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] The ability for a customer to withdraw consent to an individual Third Party Transaction exists up until the point where the transaction can no longer be revoked, as defined by Rule 20.8.2. [#P:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]
question: If a business customer and a Third Party Provider agree in writing, can they ignore the rule about revoking a payment order, and what happens to transactions if consent is withdrawn?

gold_answer: When a Fund Manager intends to use the passporting procedures for a Private Fund, it must first notify the Regulator of this intention [#TGT:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb]. If, after this notification and before the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is likely relevant to the notification, it is required to inform the Regulator in writing without delay [#SRC:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6]. The Regulator will then promptly communicate these details to the relevant Host Regulator [#SRC:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].
pred_answer: If a material change, error, or omission occurs after a Fund Manager has notified the Regulator of its intention to use passporting procedures for a Private Fund, the Fund Manager must ensure continued compliance with applicable legislation, including the Rules. Should these circumstances lead to non-compliance, or if the Regulator deems it necessary, the Regulator is empowered to take appropriate measures, which may include the de-registration of the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds. [#P:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Furthermore, the Fund Manager is obligated to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Specific events requiring such notification, within seven days of becoming aware, include the Fund Manager's intention to retire, the proposed appointment of a successor manager, the removal or replacement of the Fund Manager, changes concerning material service providers (such as custodians), amendments or replacements to the Prospectus, the commencement of winding-up proceedings, or the Fund Manager's intention to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission. [#P:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]
question: What are the obligations of a Fund Manager when a material change occurs after notifying the Regulator of its intention to use passporting procedures for a Private Fund?

gold_answer: The Regulator may disclose a statement made by a person during an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings only if the person consents to the disclosure or if the Regulator is required by law or court order to do so [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6]. Similarly, the Investigator is prohibited from disclosing such a statement unless the same conditions are met: consent from the person or a legal or court mandate [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]. This ensures that both the Regulator and the Investigator adhere to the same confidentiality obligations regarding statements made under section 206(1)(a).
pred_answer: The Regulator may disclose a statement made by a person during an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR to a law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person only under specific conditions, and this is governed by the Investigator's obligations as well. [#P:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6, #P:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951, #P:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] The primary conditions for such disclosure are that the person concerned must consent to the disclosure, or the Regulator must be legally required by law or a court order to disclose the statement. [#P:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6, #P:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] In instances where the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for an individual's interview answers for criminal proceedings, the Regulator will generally notify the person of the request. [#P:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] This notification provides the individual an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request, unless the Regulator is already compelled by law or a court order to disclose the information. [#P:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The Investigator, who conducts interviews under section 206(1)(a), is also bound by these restrictions and shall not disclose such statements to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings unless the person consents or a legal or court order mandates disclosure. [#P:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff, #P:6aa4e320-
question: Under what conditions may the Regulator disclose a statement made by a person during an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings, and how does this relate to the Investigator's obligations?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person should evaluate its exposure to interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book activities by considering a sudden and unexpected parallel change in interest rates of 200 basis points in both directions [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6]. If it has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must measure the risk exposures in each of the material currencies [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person with balance sheet positions in different currencies must measure its risk exposures in each of the material currencies to evaluate its exposure to interest rate risk arising from its Non-Trading Book activities. [#P:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] This evaluation should be integrated into the Authorised Person's enterprise-wide risk management framework and daily risk management practices. [#P:8702408d-32f7-4218-8472-f72dc2179db8] The measurement system should be capable of assessing risk under an earnings approach, and depending on the scale and complexity of the Non-Trading Book structure, may also need to measure risk based on an economic value approach. [#P:8702408d-32f7-4218-8472-f72dc2179db8] The framework should include processes and procedures that clearly document and reflect consideration of interest rate risk associated with the balance sheet structure, including various asset and liability positions, and these should be reviewed and approved by senior management. [#P:8702408d-32f7-4218-8472-f72dc2179db8] Furthermore, the Authorised Person must measure its vulnerability to loss under stressed market conditions, which may include changes in the liquidity of key financial markets or changes in the volatility of market rates. [#P:d3748bb6-db0d-448d-aa31-908d1e6a5794] The approach to evaluating and managing this risk, as part of its ICAAP, should cover issues such as the internal definition of "Non Trading Book," the treatment of multi-currency interest rate exposures, and the inclusion of non-interest-bearing assets and liabilities. [#P:1c4ed331-9364-4090-9f2c-ebdabcebff4e]
question: What should an Authorised Person do to check its interest rate risk if it has balance sheet positions in different currencies?

gold_answer: A FinTech Participant must stop its activities in the RegLab if it cannot meet the required criteria within two years [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. This must happen when their Financial Services Permission (FSP) expires or if the Regulator decides to change or cancel the FSP [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The Regulator can take the initiative to vary or cancel the permission, which affects when and how the FinTech Participant must stop its activities [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a].
pred_answer:
A FinTech Participant must cease carrying on Regulated Activities within the RegLab upon the expiry of its RegLab Financial Services Permission (FSP), unless an application to extend the two-year validity period is made at least three months prior to its expiry or as otherwise agreed by the Regulator [#P:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7, #P:c58f02e6-0701-4d82-899f-a693d180b776]. Failure to satisfy the necessary criteria by the FSP expiry date necessitates exiting the RegLab, either by migrating to the full authorisation regime or employing an exit strategy [#P:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7, #P:c58f02e6-0701-4d82-899f-a693d180b776]. The Regulator plays a significant role in managing a FinTech Participant's permission, with the ability to vary or cancel the FSP [#P:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7].

The Regulator may cancel an FSP on its own initiative if it appears that:
*   the FinTech Participant is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the Threshold Conditions made under section 7(2) of the FSMR, which include having adequate resources, being fit and proper, and possessing relevant knowledge and experience [#P:a196fe29-bdce-4820-ad63-7fbde525c991, #P:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d].
*   it is desirable to do so to further the Regulator's objectives, such as the FinTech Participant failing to meet authorisation requirements detailed in section 5.2(b)-(f) or limitations/conditions outlined in section 7.1 [#P:a196fe29-bd
question: When does a FinTech Participant have to stop its activities in the RegLab, and what role does the Regulator play in changing or cancelling their permission?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to notify the Regulator in writing of any specified event as soon as possible after becoming aware of it, subject to certain conditions [#TGT:3d835145-580b-48d8-94bf-850d0a5b3502]. This notification process is crucial when considering whether a person has become an unacceptable Controller, as the Regulator may take into account such notifications in their assessment [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. The assessment of whether a person is an acceptable Controller involves considerations outlined in a specific paragraph, which may be influenced by the notifications received from Authorised Persons [#SRC:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator about a Controller in specific circumstances related to the acquisition or increase of control, which directly informs the Regulator's assessment of whether that Controller is acceptable. The Regulator may consider a person an unacceptable Controller as a result of notifications given by a firm, including those under GEN 8.8.11(2), or through supervisory work [#P:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. If the Regulator determines an existing Controller is unacceptable, they must notify the Controller and the Authorised Person in writing and may require specific actions from both parties [#P:700c56f8-6306-45c7-802d-f8479f2bd069]. Furthermore, a person notified as an unacceptable Controller must not proceed with any proposed acquisition of control of the Authorised Person [#P:7634a2d6-9c5d-433a-89a2-6610fb5bbc18]. The Regulator issues a final notice to approve a person as a Controller, approve them subject to conditions, or declare them unacceptable, which may necessitate the disposal of their holdings [#P:ed5a6e8d-910e-40a1-bc99-a3e047d570f1, #P:a84ca5b1-3e5c-4db0-877c-892c2bd34e4b]. The Regulator's powers in relation to an unacceptable Controller include requiring the Authorised Person or the Controller to take specified actions [#P:219dc916-c224-40af-af0b-4a217189ef54].
question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person notify the Regulator about a Controller, and how does this relate to the assessment of an unacceptable Controller?

gold_answer: A letter of credit is deemed a qualifying letter of credit if it satisfies two main conditions: it must meet the requirements outlined in Rule 3.1.4(2), and it must be permitted by the Regulator to be included as eligible capital under Rule 2(2)(a) [#SRC:09531ba6-44f7-4113-bdf4-943582ecc05c]. The specific requirements of Rule 3.1.4(2) include that the letter of credit must be unconditional and irrevocable, without a subordination clause, and legally enforceable in ADGM or another approved jurisdiction [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]. Additionally, it cannot be cancelled or amended without consent from all parties, must be for a fixed amount, and renewable annually. The terms must not require the Captive Insurer to provide collateral to the bank, and the issuing bank must be rated at least BBB+ by Standard & Poor's or equivalent, and be regulated in an approved jurisdiction [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3].
pred_answer: A letter of credit is considered a qualifying letter of credit if it meets the requirements outlined in Rule 3.1.4(2) and is permitted by the Regulator to be included as eligible capital under Rule 2(2)(a) [#P:09531ba6-44f7-4113-bdf4-943582ecc05c]. To meet the requirements of Rule 3.1.4(2), the letter of credit must be unconditional and irrevocable [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]. It must not contain a subordination clause [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3], and it must be legally enforceable in ADGM or another jurisdiction approved by the Regulator [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]. Furthermore, it cannot be cancelled or amended without the consent of all parties [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3], must be for a fixed amount [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3], and must be renewable annually [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]. The terms of the agreement between the bank and the Captive Insurer should not require the Captive Insurer to provide collateral for the letter of credit [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3]. The issuing bank must be rated at least BBB+ by Standard & Poor's or an equivalent rating agency, and must be regulated in ADGM or an approved jurisdiction at the time of issue and thereafter [#P:27f296e6-bc33-466
question: Under what conditions can a letter of credit be considered a qualifying letter of credit, and what specific requirements must it meet according to Rule 3.1.4(2)?

gold_answer: The MV of Securities and the value of Collateral should be calculated in accordance with the CRM provisions as outlined in Section 4.13 [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. For reverse repurchase agreements, the calculation involves determining the amount paid or the Collateral given in relation to the MV of the Securities received [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]. This ensures that the valuation aligns with the specified provisions and accurately reflects the financial position in such agreements.
pred_answer: The Market Value (MV) of Securities and the value of Collateral for reverse repurchase agreements under the Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) provisions are determined in accordance with Section 4.13 of the CRM provisions [#P:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d]. Specifically, for reverse repurchase agreements, the amount 'E' is defined as the MV of the Securities received, which equates to the amount paid or Collateral given [#P:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]. These agreements, along with repurchase agreements, Securities and commodities borrowing, or Securities and commodities lending transactions, must be included in an Authorised Person's Trading Book if certain conditions are met. These conditions include daily marking to market (with an exception for cash borrowed or lent with a residual maturity of one month or less), adjustment of Collateral to reflect changes in the value of involved Securities or commodities, and provisions for automatic and immediate offset of claims in case of counterparty default [#P:01b1b9ad-9546-48d3-90c8-b0b38be3fbcd]. Furthermore, such agreements must be confined to accepted and appropriate uses, excluding artificial transactions, especially those not of a short-term nature [#P:01b1b9ad-9546-48d3-90c8-b0b38be3fbcd]. Collateral should be revalued frequently, ideally on at least a daily basis for marketable Securities, and potential unsecured exposures should be monitored under both stressed and normal conditions [#P:04a560e9-2ea4-42d2-a084-59dd5beead8d].
question: How should the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral be calculated for reverse repurchase agreements under the CRM provisions?

gold_answer: The Regulator may issue a direction to a Recognised Body concerning its Controllers if it deems the direction desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81]. In determining the appropriateness of exercising such powers, the Regulator will consider all relevant information and factors, including the Rules contained in MIR, the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body, and the extent to which any failure or likely failure to satisfy one or more of the Recognition Requirements may affect its objectives [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6].
pred_answer: The Regulator may issue a direction to a Recognised Body concerning its Controllers if it considers it desirable to do so in order to advance one or more of its operational objectives [#P:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81]. In determining whether to exercise this power, the Regulator will have regard to any relevant statements of policy that are currently in force [#P:3e8a3e8d-fb43-4920-aa1b-5daedb5ea8ea]. The Regulator's decision to issue directions under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2 will also take into account the Rules contained in MIR, the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body, and the extent to which a failure to satisfy Recognition Requirements may affect the Regulator's objectives [#P:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]. The procedures followed generally involve providing written notice stating the intended action and the reasons, inviting representations within a specified period, considering any representations made, and then notifying the Recognised Body of the final decision in writing [#P:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. However, these procedures may not be followed if the Recognised Body consents, or if the Regulator deems it reasonably necessary to deviate from or shorten the procedure when proposing to make a direction [#P:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd].
question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator issue a direction to a Recognised Body concerning its Controllers, and what factors will the Regulator consider in determining the appropriateness of exercising such powers?

gold_answer: The Regulator can share Confidential Information with a Non-ADGM Regulator if it follows the rules in sections 198 or 199 of the FSMR [#SRC:1c83f212-bd45-4299-b2e1-66ed94f62623]. This happens when the Regulator uses its powers under sections 215, 216, or 217 because a Non-ADGM Regulator asked for help or the Regulator is acting for them [#SRC:1c83f212-bd45-4299-b2e1-66ed94f62623]. This sharing is part of the Regulator's role in cooperating and supporting Non-ADGM Regulators, especially in investigations [#TGT:bb0aeccc-f1be-4acb-994d-4f6f37faf839].
pred_answer: The Regulator may share Confidential Information with a Non-ADGM Regulator to facilitate the carrying out of a Public Function, or when exercising its Own-Initiative Powers or Investigative Powers at the request of a Non-ADGM Regulator. [#P:681ba212-fa8c-4e83-a82a-cfd0139c3a91, #P:30321c41-3b60-4c89-8840-ba67df61afaa] Such disclosure is permitted under specific sections of the FSMR, including Section 199(2), and may be subject to conditions outlined in a memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the Non-ADGM Regulator. [#P:681ba212-fa8c-4e83-a82a-cfd0139c3a91] These conditions often stipulate that the Non-ADGM Regulator may only use the information for its identified lawful purpose and cannot voluntarily disclose it to a third party without the Regulator's further consent, unless compelled by a court order or subpoena, in which case notice must be given to the Regulator prior to disclosure, provided it does not violate applicable laws. [#P:681ba212-fa8c-4e83-a82a-cfd0139c3a91] Confidential Information gathered as a result of the Regulator exercising powers under sections 215, 216, or 217 on behalf of a Non-ADGM Regulator can only be disclosed in accordance with sections 198 or 199 of the FSMR. [#P:1c83f212-bd45-4299-b2e1-66ed94f62623] The Regulator will generally not notify affected parties of a request for Confidential Information, unless such notification is not contrary to the public interest and would not frustrate the purpose of the disclosure. [#P:681ba212-fa8c-4e83-a82a-cfd0139c3a91]
question: When can the Regulator share Confidential Information with a Non-ADGM Regulator, and how does this relate to helping them?

gold_answer: The Regulator can disqualify an auditor or actuary if they have broken the rules [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. They will look at how serious the rule-breaking is, including if it could hurt customers, harm the ADGM's reputation, or lead to financial crime [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
pred_answer: The Regulator may disqualify an auditor or actuary from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, or any particular class thereof, if the Regulator considers that a contravention of the Regulations has occurred. [#P:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] In making this decision and determining the scope of any disqualification, the Regulator will consider all circumstances, including the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effect. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] Key factors include whether the contravention resulted or is likely to result in loss to customers, damage to the reputation of the ADGM, or an increased risk of the entity being used for financial crime. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The Regulator will also take into account any remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, any disciplinary actions by a professional body, and the previous compliance record and disciplinary history of the individual. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] It is important to note that an auditor or actuary does not contravene their duties by providing information or opinions to the Regulator in good faith, provided they reasonably believe it is relevant to the Regulator's functions. [#P:776d1ff0-1fb2-4c2a-b76b-c225de1d187e] The power to disqualify auditors and actuaries is a serious one, with significant consequences for those concerned and their clients. [#P:3ac4505d-6241-4a81-8cab-997aeadfd406]
question: When can the Regulator stop an auditor or actuary from working with certain financial groups, and what factors do they look at?

gold_answer: Improper disclosure of Inside Information by an Officer or Employee of an Issuer occurs when they selectively brief analysts about undisclosed developments, which is not in the proper course of their employment duties. This action contravenes section 92(3) as it involves sharing sensitive information with analysts before it is disclosed to the market [#SRC:95f79fc9-f00f-4f1f-a811-683ca34ed4a1]. Such selective briefing is outside the proper course of employment, as it bypasses the formal disclosure processes intended to ensure market fairness [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b].
pred_answer: Selective briefing of analysts by an Officer or Employee of an Issuer about undisclosed developments constitutes an improper disclosure of Inside Information, as it falls outside the proper course of their employment, profession, or duties. Section 92(3) of the FSMR prohibits an Insider from disclosing Inside Information to another person unless it is made in accordance with their employment, office, profession, or duties [#P:ecc61e9a-8e78-4813-b5ee-b57fdb74268a, #P:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b, #P:8f77978a-8215-43c3-a41b-20e6843ea3a6, #P:2099b5f8-78a0-43e7-8fc5-0295f590463e]. This prohibition is contravened when Inside Information is disclosed otherwise than in the proper course of exercising one's employment, profession, or duties [#P:d437551a-aae1-4d57-94a7-fb36d8b2f879]. Specific examples provided by the Regulator that may contravene section 92(3) include the selective briefing of analysts by Officers or Employees of an Issuer about developments that have not yet been disclosed to the market [#P:2099b5f8-78a0-43e7-8fc5-0295f590463e, #P:89885007-8051-4fb2-acca-1ff30ef4ead7]. Such actions are viewed as improper disclosure because they do not align with the necessary course of business or the fulfillment of professional responsibilities [#P:ecc61e9a-8e78-4813-b5ee-b57fdb74268a].
question: How does the improper disclosure of Inside Information by an Officer or Employee of an Issuer to analysts relate to the concept of disclosure outside the proper course of duties?

gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is exempt from complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation if it adheres to Rules 11.7.2, 11.7.3, 11.7.4, and 11.7.6 [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. For subsequent disclosures of Non-Equivalent Estimates that initially complied with Rule 11.7.3, the entity does not need to include the information from that Rule if the subsequent disclosure references the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms the continued applicability of the earlier information, and states that there is no new material information affecting the estimates' reliability or verification as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
pred_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is exempt from complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, provided it adheres to Rules 11.7.2, 11.7.3, 11.7.4, and 11.7.6 [#P:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. Non-Equivalent Estimates are defined as estimates classified under a reporting standard not deemed a Mining Reporting Standard by the FSRA [#P:3fdfc78f-85cc-42f1-95f0-401ce0bdaca5]. Subsequent disclosures concerning these Non-Equivalent Estimates, which initially complied with Rule 11.7.3, do not need to repeat all the information from that rule if they meet specific conditions. These conditions include referencing the earlier compliant disclosure, confirming that the previously provided information remains applicable and that no new material information impacts the estimates' reliability or the entity's ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves [#P:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4]. Additionally, the subsequent disclosure must contain a statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that is at least as prominent and proximate as the statement required by Rule 11.7.3(1) [#P:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4]. If a Mining Reporting Entity cannot comply with Rules 11.7.3 to 11.7.6, it is prohibited from disclosing the Non-Equivalent Estimate [#P:7c33db9f-4fb4-48d6-b75f-fdec4a42b33c].
question: Under what conditions is a Mining Reporting Entity exempt from complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, and how does this relate to subsequent disclosures under Rule 11.7.3?

gold_answer: The Regulator can instruct a Recognised Body to take certain actions if it believes it's necessary after considering all relevant information, such as the MIR Rules, supervision results, and how not meeting Recognition Requirements might affect its goals [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]. These actions might include allowing the Regulator to inspect the premises or documents, or stopping certain activities for a set time [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500].
pred_answer: The Regulator can direct a Recognised Body to do or not do specific things, provided these actions are within the Recognised Body's powers under its Default Rules, when the Recognised Body has taken action either voluntarily or in response to a prior direction. [#P:6697146a-b9e9-4efc-a1a2-830a414820a1] Such directions may include requiring a Recognised Body to perform specified actions, such as closing the market, suspending transactions, or prohibiting trading in Investments. [#P:1a716e20-7c32-4bda-b307-8568c152835c] However, there are limitations on the Regulator's ability to issue such directions. If the Recognised Body is acting under a Regulator's direction due to undue risk to investors or market participants, the Regulator will only issue further directions if satisfied they will not impede the default proceedings. [#P:6697146a-b9e9-4efc-a1a2-830a414820a1] Similarly, if the Recognised Body acted under its Default Rules without a prior direction, the Regulator will not issue further directions unless satisfied that they will not impede the default proceedings, or if the direction is necessary for the stability of the ADGM Financial System, to facilitate a power under COBS 16, or in connection with a specific exercise of a power under COBS 16. [#P:6697146a-b9e9-4efc-a1a2-830a414820a1] The Regulator also has the power to direct a Recognised Body or Remote Body to do or not do things specified in a Direction, where the Recognised Body or Remote Body has taken or been directed to take action under its Default Rules. [#P:04d9fa32-cf1c-4f20-ad48-171624e098f5]
question: When can the Regulator tell a Recognised Body to do certain things, and what might those things be?

gold_answer: Behaviour constitutes market manipulation under Section 92(4) of the FSMR when it involves effecting transactions or orders to trade that are not for legitimate reasons and do not conform with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market [#SRC:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b]. Such Behaviour must either give or be likely to give a false or misleading impression regarding the supply, demand, or price of Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities, or secure the price of these instruments at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].
pred_answer: Behaviour constitutes market manipulation under Section 92(4) of the FSMR when it involves effecting transactions or orders to trade that are not for legitimate reasons and do not conform with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and which either give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression regarding the supply, demand, or price of financial instruments, accepted virtual assets, or accepted spot commodities, or secure the price of these at an abnormal or artificial level [#P:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b, #P:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. The requirement for conformity with Accepted Market Practices is a key element in determining whether such behaviour is manipulative; if conduct is carried out for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, it does not constitute market manipulation [#P:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]. Conversely, behaviour that does not meet these criteria, specifically by being outside of legitimate reasons and Accepted Market Practices, can be considered market manipulation if it creates a false or misleading impression or secures an artificial price level [#P:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b, #P:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. It is important to note that certain behaviours are explicitly excluded from being considered market abuse, such as those conforming with specific Rules, Price Stabilisation Rules, or actions taken by a person acting on behalf of a public authority in the legitimate exercise of its public functions [#P:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1].
question: Under what conditions does Behaviour constitute market manipulation according to Section 92(4) of the FSMR, and how does this relate to the requirement for conformity with Accepted Market Practices?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person cannot use a Client's Virtual Assets for staking without the Client's prior written permission [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. The Regulator considers using Virtual Assets for staking as a use for the Authorised Person's own purpose [#SRC:ee60daeb-c185-4221-bf81-7a1bbeb8badc]. Therefore, written consent from the Client is necessary before proceeding with such use [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098].
pred_answer: An Authorised Person cannot use a Client's Virtual Assets for staking without that Client's prior written permission. Rule 15.4.4 explicitly prohibits an Authorised Person from using a Client's Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person without obtaining the Client's prior written consent. [#P:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098] The Regulator considers the use of Virtual Assets for staking to be a use for the purposes of the Authorised Person. [#P:ee60daeb-c185-4221-bf81-7a1bbeb8badc] Therefore, to engage in staking activities with a Client's Virtual Assets, the Authorised Person must first secure explicit written authorization from the Client. This requirement is in place to protect Client assets and ensure that any use beyond safekeeping is explicitly agreed upon.
question: Can an Authorised Person use a Client's Virtual Assets for staking without permission?

gold_answer: Before using an eKYC System, a Relevant Person should ensure the system is reliable and independent to comply with the Regulator's Rules [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]. Additionally, before hiring a service provider for Customer Due Diligence (CDD), the Relevant Person must assess the provider's suitability and document their obligations in a binding agreement [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752]. Both actions are necessary to ensure compliance and proper documentation.
pred_answer:
Before a Relevant Person utilizes an eKYC System and engages a service provider for Customer Due Diligence (CDD), a comprehensive assurance assessment of the eKYC System is mandatory to ensure its reliability, independence, and compliance with all applicable Rules. [#P:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] This assessment is a prerequisite for appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, and it must evaluate the suitability of the service provider, with their obligations clearly documented in a binding agreement. [#P:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] The use of a service provider's eKYC System is considered outsourcing for the purposes of Rule 9.3.1. [#P:6e9eb8a0-c497-47c1-89e0-7cb118e75ec3]

The Relevant Person must ensure the eKYC System allows for full compliance with relevant CDD Rules, including those related to the identification and verification of Beneficial Owners. [#P:d9daffbe-8401-47ce-80e6-9218158f3511] Appropriate measures must be implemented to mitigate risks associated with eKYC processes, ensuring the system is secure, effective, and at least as stringent as face-to-face CDD, incorporating suitable authentication factors and verifying the authenticity of identification documents and the customer. [#P:aecde7ad-d719-4416-b520-a9e53a58934f] Furthermore, the Relevant Person should have a thorough understanding of the eKYC System and its associated risks, including those outlined by FATF and other international standard-setting bodies, and comply with all relevant Regulator Rules, such as those concerning business risk assessment and outsourcing. [#P:cb40cc9f-1271-40bd-8bc6-2f4e6fce615a] Transaction monitoring, anti-fraud, and cyber-security measures should be combined with eKYC to prevent Financial Crime, and steps must be taken to identify, assess, and mitigate the risk of the
question: What should a Relevant Person do before using an eKYC System and hiring a service provider for CDD?

gold_answer: Securities can be sold without a current Prospectus if they are classified as Exempt Securities by the Regulator. These include shares that make up less than 10% of a class already traded over a year, or shares issued as a substitute without increasing capital [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. This is possible when exemptions under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 apply, allowing such sales without needing a current Prospectus [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38].
pred_answer:
Securities can be sold without a current Prospectus if the offer constitutes an "Exempt Offer" or if the securities themselves are classified as "Exempt Securities." [#P:11] An Exempt Offer is an offer of securities that does not require a Prospectus, as specified by the Regulator under section 58(1) of the FSMR. [#P:2] Exempt Securities are those that can be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange without a Prospectus. [#P:8]

The Regulator prescribes specific circumstances under which an offer is considered exempt. These include offers directed solely at Professional Clients, offers to fewer than 50 persons in a 12-month period (excluding professional clients who are not natural persons), or offers where the total consideration is at least USD 100,000 or an equivalent amount. [#P:5, #P:7] Other exempt offers encompass shares issued in substitution for existing shares without increasing capital, securities offered in connection with takeovers or mergers if equivalent information is available, rights issues with specific documentation, shares offered free of charge or as stock dividends to existing shareholders with accompanying documentation, and offers to existing or former directors or employees under certain conditions. [#P:7] Additionally, securities offered in connection with specific issues under Rules 9.7.1 or 9.7.4, and securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange for over 18 months with ongoing obligations met and a summary document approved by the Regulator, are also considered exempt offers. [#P:4]

Exempt Securities are defined by the Regulator under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR and include shares representing less than 10% of the number of shares of the same class already admitted to trading over 12 months, shares issued in substitution for existing shares without increasing capital, securities offered in connection with takeovers or mergers if equivalent documentation is available, securities in connection with rights issues meeting specific criteria, shares offered free of charge or as stock dividends to existing shareholders with documentation, securities offered to existing or former directors or employees with specific conditions, shares resulting from the conversion or exchange of other securities of the same class, and securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange for over 18 months with compliance and summary document requirements. [#P:4]
question: When can Securities be sold without a current Prospectus, and what types of Securities are considered exempt by the Regulator?

gold_answer: An order is classified as large in scale compared to normal market size if it meets or exceeds the minimum size specified in Rule 3.5.11 [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]. The classification of Financial Instruments is determined by their average daily turnover, as outlined in Rule 3.5.12 [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]. The minimum size of an order qualifying as large in scale varies based on the average daily turnover (ADT) of the instrument: for ADT less than or equal to USD 500,000, the minimum size is USD 50,000; for ADT between USD 500,000 and USD 1,000,000, it is USD 100,000; for ADT between USD 1,000,000 and USD 25,000,000, it is USD 250,000; for ADT between USD 25,000,000 and USD 50,000,000, it is USD 400,000; and for ADT greater than USD 50,000,000, the minimum size is USD 500,000 [#TGT:4d8f4efe-e1c0-4b4a-aafd-32081fee4d4b].
pred_answer: An order is classified as large in scale compared with normal market size if it meets or exceeds a minimum order size specified by the Recognised Investment Exchange, which is determined by the average daily turnover (ADT) of the Financial Instrument traded. [#P:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627] To establish this classification, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange are categorized based on their ADT in USD. [#P:4d8f4efe-e1c0-4b4a-aafd-32081fee4d4b] The minimum order size qualifying as large in scale varies according to these ADT bands: for instruments with ADT less than or equal to $500,000, the minimum size is $50,000; for ADT between $500,000 and $1,000,000, it is $100,000; for ADT between $1,000,000 and $25,000,000, it is $250,000; for ADT between $25,000,000 and $50,000,000, it is $400,000; and for ADT greater than $50,000,000, it is $500,000. [#P:4d8f4efe-e1c0-4b4a-aafd-32081fee4d4b] These criteria are relevant for determining eligibility for waivers from certain rules, such as the deferred publication of large transactions, provided the transaction is between a Member or Authorised Person dealing on their own account and a client, and the size meets or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size. [#P:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] Waivers may also be granted by the Regulator for orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size, even for Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7. [#P:63e56280-5a41
question: How is an order classified as large in scale compared to normal market size for Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and what are the minimum size requirements based on average daily turnover?

gold_answer: The Regulator is required to consult the Recognised Body before issuing a direction under both Rule 6.5.4 and Rule 6.5.6. For Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator must be satisfied that failure to act would pose undue risk to investors or market participants, that the direction is necessary for public interest in financial stability, or that it facilitates a proposed or possible use of power under chapter 16 of COBS or Rule 6.5.7(c) [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]. For Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator must determine that taking action would be premature or undesirable for investors or market participants, that the direction is necessary for public interest in financial stability, or that it facilitates a proposed or possible use of power under chapter 16 of COBS or a particular exercise of power under that Part [#TGT:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3].
pred_answer: Before issuing a direction under Rule 6.5.4 or Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator is obligated to consult the Recognised Body in question [#P:6.5.5, #P:6.5.7, #P:6.5.3]. The Regulator shall not issue a direction unless, following this consultation, it is satisfied that specific conditions are met. For a "positive" direction under Rule 6.5.4, where the Recognised Body has not taken action but could, the Regulator must be satisfied that failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other market participants [#P:6.5.5(a), #P:6.5.4]. For a "negative" direction under Rule 6.5.6, where the Recognised Body is proposing or may take action, the Regulator must be satisfied that taking such action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other market participants [#P:6.5.7(a), #P:6.5.6]. In either case, the Regulator must also be satisfied that the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market [#P:6.5.5(b), #P:6.5.7(b)]. Additionally, the direction must be necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter or Rule 6.5.7(c) [#P:6.5.5(c), #P:6.5.7(c)]. A similar consultation requirement and satisfaction criteria apply to directions issued under Part 13.162.(3), encompassing risks to investors and the stability of the ADGM Financial System [#P:17,Part 13.162.(3)].
question: Under what conditions must the Regulator consult the Recognised Body before issuing a direction under Rule 6.5.4 or Rule 6.5.6, and what are the necessary considerations for the Regulator to be satisfied with the direction?
